title: Data Wrangling in R
text:
Workshop Overview


Import: Getting data into R
Explore: Understanding data structures
Clean: Handling messy data
Transform: Reshaping and manipulating data
Combine: Merging datasets



This workshop focuses on the essential data wrangling skills needed before analysis.

title: Data Wrangling in R
text:
What is Data Wrangling?


The process of transforming raw data into a format suitable for analysis


Image credit: Allison Horst

title: Data Wrangling in R
text:
What is the Tidyverse?


A collection of R packages designed for data science
Created by Hadley Wickham and team at Posit (formerly RStudio)
Shares common philosophy, grammar, and data structures
Makes data science faster, easier, and more fun!

title: Data Wrangling in R
text:
Tidyverse Philosophy


Design Principles


Tidy data as foundation
Pipe-friendly functions
Human-readable code
Consistent syntax
Composable operations



Key Features


Functions do one thing well
First argument is always data
Works with pipes (|> or %>%)
Returns tibbles
Excellent documentation

title: Data Wrangling in R
text:
Installation & Loading


Install (once)

# Installs all tidyverse packages
install.packages("tidyverse")




Load (every session)

# Loads the 8 core packages
library(tidyverse)




What gets loaded?

# ── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──
# ✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
# ✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.1
# ✔ ggplot2   3.5.1     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
# ✔ lubridate 1.9.3     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
# ✔ purrr     1.0.2

title: Data Wrangling in R
text:
Loading Additional Packages

Some tidyverse packages need explicit loading:



library(tidyverse)  # Loads core 8
library(lubridate)  # Need to load explicitly
library(readxl)     # Need to load explicitly
library(haven)      # Need to load explicitly



Why? These are specialized packages not needed for every analysis

title: Data Wrangling in R
text:
Workshop Focus


readr & readxl - Import data
dplyr - Manipulate data (select, filter, mutate, etc.)
tidyr - Reshape data (pivot_longer, pivot_wider)
lubridate - Work with dates
forcats - Handle factors
janitor - Clean messy data (not tidyverse, but tidyverse-friendly!)

text:

Core Functions:


Data Import
dplyr

Specialized:


stringr
forcats
lubridate
All Cheatsheets

title: Data Wrangling in R
text:
Why Use Tidyverse?


Readability

# Base R
result <- aggregate(
  bp_data$sys_bp_0m,
  by = list(bp_data$region),
  FUN = mean,
  na.rm = TRUE
)


Tidyverse

# Tidyverse
result <- bp_data |> 
  group_by(region) |> 
  summarise(
    mean_bp = mean(sys_bp_0m)
  )




Tidyverse code reads like sentences!

title: Data Wrangling in R
text:
Importing CSV Files

Question: How do I read a CSV file?



# Base R
data <- read.csv("data.csv")




# Tidyverse (readr) - Recommended
data <- read_csv("data.csv")




# With pipe operator
data <- "data.csv" |> read_csv()

title: Data Wrangling in R
text:
Importing Excel Files


library(readxl)




# Read first sheet
data <- read_excel("data.xlsx")




# Specify sheet by name
data <- read_excel("data.xlsx", sheet = "Sheet1")




# Specify sheet by number
data <- read_excel("data.xlsx", sheet = 2)

title: Data Wrangling in R
text:
Importing SPSS/SAS/Stata Files


library(haven)




# SPSS
data <- read_sav("data.sav")




# SAS
data <- read_sas("data.sas7bdat")




# Stata
data <- read_dta("data.dta")

title: Data Wrangling in R
text:
Tidy Data Principles



Each variable is a column
Each observation is a row
Each value is a cell

title: Data Wrangling in R
text:
Vectors



# Numeric vector
ages <- c(25, 30, 45, 60)
ages

#> [1] 25 30 45 60





# Character vector
regions <- c("North", "South", "East", "West")
regions

#> [1] "North" "South" "East"  "West"

title: Data Wrangling in R
text:
Lists

Lists can contain different types of objects



patient_info <- list(
  id = 101,
  name = "John Doe",
  age = 45,
  bp_readings = c(120, 125, 118)
)




patient_info$age

#> [1] 45

title: Data Wrangling in R
text:
Data Frames vs Tibbles


Data Frame

df <- data.frame(
  id = 1:3,
  name = c("A", "B", "C")
)
df

#>   id name
#> 1  1    A
#> 2  2    B
#> 3  3    C



Tibble

tb <- tibble(
  id = 1:3,
  name = c("A", "B", "C")
)
tb

#> # A tibble: 3 × 2
#>      id name 
#>   <int> <chr>
#> 1     1 A    
#> 2     2 B    
#> 3     3 C





Tibbles are modern data frames with better printing and stricter behavior

title: Data Wrangling in R
text:
The Janitor Package



library(janitor)

title: Data Wrangling in R
text:
Cleaning Column Names


# Before
names(bp_data)[1:5]

#> [1] "PatientID"      "TreatmentGroup" "Age"            "Gender"        
#> [5] "Region"





# Clean names
bp_clean <- bp_data |> 
  clean_names()

names(bp_clean)[1:5]

#> [1] "patient_id"      "treatment_group" "age"             "gender"         
#> [5] "region"




All names are now lowercase and use underscores!

title: Data Wrangling in R
text:
Handling Missing Values

Question: Which variables have missing data?



bp_clean |> 
  summarise(across(everything(), ~sum(is.na(.))))

#> # A tibble: 1 × 22
#>   patient_id treatment_group   age gender region smoking_status alcohol_use
#>        <int>           <int> <int>  <int>  <int>          <int>       <int>
#> 1          0               0     0      0      0              0           0
#> # ℹ 15 more variables: bmi <int>, exercise_freq <int>, chronic_disease <int>,
#> #   vaccinated <int>, cholesterol <int>, blood_sugar <int>, latitude <int>,
#> #   longitude <int>, baseline_date <int>, sys_bp_0m <int>, dia_bp_0m <int>,
#> #   sys_bp_3m <int>, sys_bp_6m <int>, dia_bp_3m <int>, dia_bp_6m <int>

title: Data Wrangling in R
text:
Removing Rows with Missing Values


# Remove rows with ANY missing values
bp_complete <- bp_clean |> 
  drop_na()




nrow(bp_clean)

#> [1] 200

nrow(bp_complete)

#> [1] 196




Common Error: drop_na() without () - it’s a function!

title: Data Wrangling in R
text:
Removing Specific Missing Values

Question: Remove only rows missing exercise data



bp_exercise <- bp_clean |> 
  drop_na(exercise_freq)




nrow(bp_clean)

#> [1] 200

nrow(bp_exercise)

#> [1] 198

title: Data Wrangling in R
text:
Checking for Duplicates


# Check for duplicate patient IDs
bp_clean |> 
  get_dupes(patient_id)

#> No duplicate combinations found of: patient_id


#> # A tibble: 0 × 23
#> # ℹ 23 variables: patient_id <dbl>, dupe_count <int>, treatment_group <chr>,
#> #   age <dbl>, gender <chr>, region <chr>, smoking_status <chr>,
#> #   alcohol_use <chr>, bmi <dbl>, exercise_freq <chr>, chronic_disease <chr>,
#> #   vaccinated <chr>, cholesterol <dbl>, blood_sugar <dbl>, latitude <dbl>,
#> #   longitude <dbl>, baseline_date <dttm>, sys_bp_0m <dbl>, dia_bp_0m <dbl>,
#> #   sys_bp_3m <dbl>, sys_bp_6m <dbl>, dia_bp_3m <dbl>, dia_bp_6m <dbl>




No duplicates found! ✓

title: Data Wrangling in R
text:
The dplyr Package


Six main verbs for data manipulation

title: Data Wrangling in R
text:
dplyr Verbs


select() - Choose columns
filter() - Choose rows
arrange() - Sort rows
mutate() - Create/modify columns
summarise() - Aggregate data
group_by() - Group operations

title: Data Wrangling in R
text:
Basic Select

Question: How do I select specific columns?



bp_clean |> 
  select(patient_id, age, gender, region)

#> # A tibble: 200 × 4
#>    patient_id   age gender region
#>         <dbl> <dbl> <chr>  <chr> 
#>  1          1    36 Female South 
#>  2          2    79 Male   South 
#>  3          3    19 Male   West  
#>  4          4    70 Female West  
#>  5          5    61 Male   West  
#>  6          6    43 Male   North 
#>  7          7    49 Male   East  
#>  8          8    23 Male   North 
#>  9          9    49 Female East  
#> 10         10    72 Male   North 
#> # ℹ 190 more rows

title: Data Wrangling in R
text:
Select: Removing Columns


# Remove columns with minus sign
bp_clean |> 
  select(-latitude, -longitude)

#> # A tibble: 200 × 20
#>    patient_id treatment_group   age gender region smoking_status alcohol_use
#>         <dbl> <chr>           <dbl> <chr>  <chr>  <chr>          <chr>      
#>  1          1 Control            36 Female South  Non-smoker     No         
#>  2          2 Control            79 Male   South  Former smoker  No         
#>  3          3 Control            19 Male   West   Former smoker  No         
#>  4          4 Intervention       70 Female West   Current smoker No         
#>  5          5 Intervention       61 Male   West   Current smoker No         
#>  6          6 Intervention       43 Male   North  Former smoker  No         
#>  7          7 Control            49 Male   East   Current smoker Yes        
#>  8          8 Intervention       23 Male   North  Former smoker  Yes        
#>  9          9 Intervention       49 Female East   Former smoker  No         
#> 10         10 Control            72 Male   North  Non-smoker     No         
#> # ℹ 190 more rows
#> # ℹ 13 more variables: bmi <dbl>, exercise_freq <chr>, chronic_disease <chr>,
#> #   vaccinated <chr>, cholesterol <dbl>, blood_sugar <dbl>,
#> #   baseline_date <dttm>, sys_bp_0m <dbl>, dia_bp_0m <dbl>, sys_bp_3m <dbl>,
#> #   sys_bp_6m <dbl>, dia_bp_3m <dbl>, dia_bp_6m <dbl>




Common Error: Forgetting the minus sign removes nothing!

title: Data Wrangling in R
text:
Select: Range of Columns

Question: Select all columns from age to bmi



bp_clean |> 
  select(age:bmi)

#> # A tibble: 200 × 6
#>      age gender region smoking_status alcohol_use   bmi
#>    <dbl> <chr>  <chr>  <chr>          <chr>       <dbl>
#>  1    36 Female South  Non-smoker     No           26.9
#>  2    79 Male   South  Former smoker  No           24.4
#>  3    19 Male   West   Former smoker  No           23.9
#>  4    70 Female West   Current smoker No           31  
#>  5    61 Male   West   Current smoker No           26.2
#>  6    43 Male   North  Former smoker  No           27.2
#>  7    49 Male   East   Current smoker Yes          27.7
#>  8    23 Male   North  Former smoker  Yes          25.7
#>  9    49 Female East   Former smoker  No           27.6
#> 10    72 Male   North  Non-smoker     No           24.4
#> # ℹ 190 more rows

title: Data Wrangling in R
text:
Select Helpers

Powerful functions to select columns by pattern



# Columns starting with "sys"
select(starts_with("sys"))




# Columns ending with "0m"
select(ends_with("0m"))




# Columns containing "bp"
select(contains("bp"))

title: Data Wrangling in R
text:
Select Helpers: starts_with()

Question: Select all systolic BP measurements



bp_clean |> 
  select(patient_id, starts_with("sys_bp"))

title: Data Wrangling in R
text:
Select Helpers: where()

Question: Select all numeric columns



bp_clean |> 
  select(where(is.numeric))

#> # A tibble: 200 × 13
#>    patient_id   age   bmi cholesterol blood_sugar latitude longitude sys_bp_0m

title: Data Wrangling in R
text:
Creating Categories from Continuous Data

Question: Create age categories




Code
bp_clean |> 
  mutate(
    age_group = case_when(
      age < 40 ~ "Young Adult",
      age >= 40 & age < 60 ~ "Middle Age",
      age >= 60 ~ "Senior"
    )
  )

text:
Using cut() for Categories



Code
bp_clean |> 
  mutate(
    age_category = cut(age, 
                       breaks = c(0, 40, 60, 100),
                       labels = c("Young", "Middle", "Senior"))

title: Data Wrangling in R
text:
Creating Hypertension Categories

Question: Classify baseline BP using clinical guidelines



bp_with_category <- bp_clean |> 
  mutate(
    bp_category = case_when(
      sys_bp_0m < 120 & dia_bp_0m < 80 ~ "Normal",
      sys_bp_0m >= 120 & sys_bp_0m < 130 & dia_bp_0m < 80 ~ "Elevated",
      (sys_bp_0m >= 130 & sys_bp_0m < 140) | 
        (dia_bp_0m >= 80 & dia_bp_0m < 90) ~ "Stage 1",
      sys_bp_0m >= 140 | dia_bp_0m >= 90 ~ "Stage 2"
    )
  )

title: Data Wrangling in R
Data Wrangling in R
text:
if_else() for Simple Conditions

Question: Create a binary high BP indicator




Code
bp_clean |> 
  mutate(
    high_bp = if_else(sys_bp_0m >= 140 | dia_bp_0m >= 90, 
                      "High", 
                      "Normal")
  )

title: Data Wrangling in R
text:
case_when() vs if_else()


if_else()

Binary outcomes
Single condition
Simpler syntax


if_else(
  condition,
  true_value,
  false_value
)


case_when()

Multiple outcomes
Multiple conditions
More flexible


case_when(
  condition1 ~ value1,
  condition2 ~ value2,
  TRUE ~ default_value
)

title: Data Wrangling in R
Data Wrangling in R
text:
lubridate Package


“Wrangle times and dates!”

title: Data Wrangling in R
text:
Why lubridate?


Dates are complex (leap years, time zones, daylight savings)
lubridate makes date operations intuitive
Part of tidyverse but must be loaded separately
Essential for healthcare data with visit dates, follow-ups

title: Data Wrangling in R
text:
Our Dataset Has Dates


bp_clean |> 
  select(patient_id, baseline_date) |> 
  head()

#> # A tibble: 6 × 2
#>   patient_id baseline_date      
#>        <dbl> <dttm>             
#> 1          1 2025-05-03 13:06:39
#> 2          2 2025-04-15 10:45:27
#> 3          3 2025-06-14 07:24:46
#> 4          4 2025-02-02 10:10:45
#> 5          5 2025-04-17 10:41:06
#> 6          6 2025-05-30 10:58:02




Let’s explore what we can do with these dates!

title: Data Wrangling in R
text:
Extract Date Components

Question: Extract year, month, and day from baseline date




Code
library(lubridate)

bp_clean |> 
  mutate(
    baseline_year = year(baseline_date),
    baseline_month = month(baseline_date),
    baseline_day = day(baseline_date)
  ) |> 
  select(patient_id, baseline_date, baseline_year, baseline_month, baseline_day)


#> # A tibble: 200 × 5
#>    patient_id baseline_date       baseline_year baseline_month baseline_day

#> 10         10 2025-03-21 03:56:29          2025              3           21
#> # ℹ 190 more rows

Month Names and Weekdays



Code
bp_clean |> 
  mutate(
    month_name = month(baseline_date, label = TRUE),

title: Data Wrangling in R
text:
Age Calculation from Dates

Question: Calculate age from birthdate




Code
# Example with made-up birthdates
example_data <- tibble(
  patient_id = 1:3,
  birthdate = ymd(c("1980-05-15", "1965-12-20", "1990-03-08")),
  visit_date = ymd(c("2024-01-15", "2024-01-15", "2024-01-15"))
)

example_data |> 
  mutate(
    age_years = interval(birthdate, visit_date) / years(1),
    age_months = interval(birthdate, visit_date) / months(1)
  )


#> # A tibble: 3 × 5
#>   patient_id birthdate  visit_date age_years age_months
#>        <int> <date>     <date>         <dbl>      <dbl>
#> 1          1 1980-05-15 2024-01-15      43.7       524 
#> 2          2 1965-12-20 2024-01-15      58.1       697.
#> 3          3 1990-03-08 2024-01-15      33.9       406.

title: Data Wrangling in R
text:
Useful lubridate Functions


Parsing: ymd(), mdy(), dmy() - parse dates
Components: year(), month(), day(), hour(), minute()
Weekdays: wday(), week()
Math: days(), weeks(), months(), years()
Intervals: interval(), time_length()
Current: today(), now()

title: Data Wrangling in R
text:
forcats::fct_infreq()


Reorder factor levels by frequency

title: Data Wrangling in R
text:
Why Reorder Factors?

Problem: Default alphabetical ordering isn’t always meaningful



# Count patients by region
bp_clean |> 
  count(region)

#> # A tibble: 4 × 2
#>   region     n
#>   <chr>  <int>
#> 1 East      41
#> 2 North     66
#> 3 South     47
#> 4 West      46




Let’s reorder by frequency for better visualization

title: Data Wrangling in R
text:
fct_infreq: Order by Frequency

Question: Which regions have the most patients?



library(forcats)

bp_clean |> 
  mutate(region = fct_infreq(region)) |> 
  count(region)

#> # A tibble: 4 × 2
#>   region     n
#>   <fct>  <int>
#> 1 North     66
#> 2 South     47
#> 3 West      46
#> 4 East      41




Now ordered from most to least common!

title: Data Wrangling in R
text:
fct_infreq in Practice



Code
# Useful for plots - bars in descending order
bp_clean |> 
  mutate(
    smoking_status = fct_infreq(smoking_status)
  ) |> 
  count(smoking_status)


#> # A tibble: 3 × 2
#>   smoking_status     n
#>   <fct>          <int>
#> 1 Non-smoker       120
#> 2 Former smoker     43
#> 3 Current smoker    37

title: Data Wrangling in R
text:
Other forcats Functions


fct_inorder() - Order by first appearance
fct_reorder() - Order by another variable
fct_relevel() - Manually reorder specific levels
fct_lump() - Combine rare categories into “Other”
fct_recode() - Manually change level names

#> 10         10 Control               135       136       133
#> # ℹ 190 more rows

title: Data Wrangling in R
Data Wrangling in R
Data Wrangling in R
text:
Creating Example Datasets


# Patient demographics
demographics <- tibble(
  patient_id = c(1, 2, 3, 4),
  age = c(45, 52, 38, 61),
  gender = c("Male", "Female", "Male", "Female")
)

# Lab results (note: not all patients)
labs <- tibble(
  patient_id = c(2, 3, 4, 5),
  cholesterol = c(180, 220, 195, 210),
  glucose = c(95, 110, 88, 105)
)

title: Data Wrangling in R
text:
inner_join()

Question: Keep only patients with both demographics AND lab results



inner_join(demographics, labs, by = "patient_id")

#> # A tibble: 3 × 5
#>   patient_id   age gender cholesterol glucose
#>        <dbl> <dbl> <chr>        <dbl>   <dbl>
#> 1          2    52 Female         180      95
#> 2          3    38 Male           220     110
#> 3          4    61 Female         195      88




Only patients 2, 3, and 4 are kept (present in both datasets)

title: Data Wrangling in R
text:
left_join()

Question: Keep all patients from demographics, add lab data where available



left_join(demographics, labs, by = "patient_id")

#> # A tibble: 4 × 5
#>   patient_id   age gender cholesterol glucose
#>        <dbl> <dbl> <chr>        <dbl>   <dbl>
#> 1          1    45 Male            NA      NA
#> 2          2    52 Female         180      95
#> 3          3    38 Male           220     110
#> 4          4    61 Female         195      88




All 4 patients kept; patient 1 has NA for lab values

title: Data Wrangling in R
text:
right_join()

Question: Keep all lab results, add demographics where available



right_join(demographics, labs, by = "patient_id")

#> # A tibble: 4 × 5
#>   patient_id   age gender cholesterol glucose
#>        <dbl> <dbl> <chr>        <dbl>   <dbl>
#> 1          2    52 Female         180      95
#> 2          3    38 Male           220     110
#> 3          4    61 Female         195      88
#> 4          5    NA <NA>           210     105




All lab records kept; patient 5 has NA for demographics

title: Data Wrangling in R
text:
full_join()

Question: Keep ALL patients from both datasets



full_join(demographics, labs, by = "patient_id")

#> # A tibble: 5 × 5
#>   patient_id   age gender cholesterol glucose
#>        <dbl> <dbl> <chr>        <dbl>   <dbl>
#> 1          1    45 Male            NA      NA
#> 2          2    52 Female         180      95
#> 3          3    38 Male           220     110
#> 4          4    61 Female         195      88
#> 5          5    NA <NA>           210     105




All 5 patients kept; NAs where data is missing

title: Data Wrangling in R
text:
Join with Pipe Operator


# More readable with pipes
demographics |> 
  left_join(labs, by = "patient_id")

#> # A tibble: 4 × 5
#>   patient_id   age gender cholesterol glucose
#>        <dbl> <dbl> <chr>        <dbl>   <dbl>
#> 1          1    45 Male            NA      NA
#> 2          2    52 Female         180      95
#> 3          3    38 Male           220     110
#> 4          4    61 Female         195      88

title: Data Wrangling in R
text:
Joining on Multiple Columns


# Create datasets with multiple keys
visits1 <- tibble(
  patient_id = c(1, 1, 2),
  visit_date = as.Date(c("2024-01-01", "2024-02-01", "2024-01-15")),
  bp = c(120, 118, 130)
)

visits2 <- tibble(
  patient_id = c(1, 1, 2),
  visit_date = as.Date(c("2024-01-01", "2024-02-01", "2024-01-15")),
  weight = c(70, 69, 85)
)

title: Data Wrangling in R
text:
Multi-Column Join


visits1 |> 
  left_join(visits2, by = c("patient_id", "visit_date"))

#> # A tibble: 3 × 4
#>   patient_id visit_date    bp weight
#>        <dbl> <date>     <dbl>  <dbl>
#> 1          1 2024-01-01   120     70
#> 2          1 2024-02-01   118     69
#> 3          2 2024-01-15   130     85




Common Error: Forgetting to specify multiple keys when needed

title: Data Wrangling in R
text:
Join with Different Column Names



Code
# Create datasets with different key names
data1 <- tibble(
  id = c(1, 2, 3),
  value_x = c(10, 20, 30)
)

data2 <- tibble(
  patient_id = c(1, 2, 3),
  value_y = c(100, 200, 300)
)





data1 |> 
  left_join(data2, by = c("id" = "patient_id"))

#> # A tibble: 3 × 3
#>      id value_x value_y
#>   <dbl>   <dbl>   <dbl>
#> 1     1      10     100
#> 2     2      20     200
#> 3     3      30     300

title: Data Wrangling in R
text:
Error: Object Not Found


Error

bp_data |> 
  select(Patient_ID)

#> Error in `select()`:
#> ! Can't select columns that don't exist.
#> ✖ Column `Patient_ID` doesn't exist.



Solution

# Column names are case-sensitive
bp_data |> 
  select(PatientID)

# Or use clean_names()
bp_clean |> 
  select(patient_id)

title: Data Wrangling in R
text:
Error: Comparison Operators


Error

bp_clean |> 
  filter(age = 50)

#> Error in `filter()`:
#> ! We detected a named input.
#> ℹ This usually means that you've used `=` instead of `==`.
#> ℹ Did you mean `age == 50`?



Solution

# Use == for comparison
bp_clean |> 
  filter(age == 50)

title: Data Wrangling in R
text:
Error: Pipe Operator


Error

bp_clean |> 
  select(age, gender)

#> # A tibble: 200 × 2
#>      age gender
#>    <dbl> <chr> 
#>  1    36 Female
#>  2    79 Male  
#>  3    19 Male  
#>  4    70 Female
#>  5    61 Male  
#>  6    43 Male  
#>  7    49 Male  
#>  8    23 Male  
#>  9    49 Female
#> 10    72 Male  
#> # ℹ 190 more rows

  filter(age > 50)

#> Error: object 'age' not found



Solution

# Need pipe between operations
bp_clean |> 
  select(age, gender) |> 
  filter(age > 50)

title: Data Wrangling in R
text:
Warning: Factor Conversion



Code
bp_clean |> 
  mutate(
    region_num = as.numeric(region)
  ) |> 
  select(region, region_num)


#> Warning: There was 1 warning in `mutate()`.
#> ℹ In argument: `region_num = as.numeric(region)`.
#> Caused by warning:
#> ! NAs introduced by coercion


#> # A tibble: 200 × 2
#>    region region_num
#>    <chr>       <dbl>
#>  1 South          NA
#>  2 South          NA
#>  3 West           NA
#>  4 West           NA
#>  5 West           NA
#>  6 North          NA
#>  7 East           NA
#>  8 North          NA
#>  9 East           NA
#> 10 North          NA
#> # ℹ 190 more rows




Converts to factor levels, not character → number. Use as.numeric(as.factor(region)) if needed.

title: Data Wrangling in R
Data Wrangling in R
text:
Tips for Troubleshooting


Build step by step - Add one operation at a time
Check intermediate results - Print after each step
Use View() - Inspect data in RStudio: View(bp_clean)
Read error messages - They usually tell you what’s wrong
Check data types - Use glimpse() or str()
Search for help - Stack Overflow, R documentation

title: Data Wrangling in R
text:
Best Practices Summary


Use consistent naming conventions (snake_case)
Clean names early with janitor::clean_names()
Pipe operations for readable code
Check your data at each step
Document your code with comments
Save intermediate results when needed
Test with small samples first

title: Categorical Base Plots
text:
Categorical Base Plots
Author: Sparrow
Creating Effective Visualizations for Categorical Data

title: Categorical Base Plots
text:
Bar Charts: Description

When to Use

Display frequency distribution of a single categorical variable
Compare categories in terms of count or frequency
Works best with 2-8 categories

Requirements

One categorical variable
Clear category labels

Advantages
✅ Easy to interpret and understand
✅ Clear comparison across categories
✅ Shows exact frequencies and percentages
✅ Universally recognized visualization
Limitations
❌ Not suitable for continuous data
❌ Overcrowded with too many categories (>10)
❌ Doesn’t show relationships between variables

title: Categorical Base Plots
text:
Bar Chart - Code
# Step 1: Calculate frequencies and percentages
gender_data <- df %>%
  count(Gender) %>%
  mutate(
    percentage = n / sum(n) * 100,
    label = paste0(n, "\n(", round(percentage, 1), "%)")
  )

# Step 2: Create bar chart with ggplot2
ggplot(gender_data, aes(x = Gender, y = n, fill = Gender)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity", width = 0.6)


# Step 3: Add text labels and styling
  geom_text(aes(label = label), vjust = -0.5, size = 4) +
  scale_fill_brewer(palette = "Set2") +
  labs(title = "Distribution by Gender", x = "Gender", y = "Frequency") +
  theme(legend.position = "none",
        plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, face = "bold", size = 14))

title: Categorical Base Plots
text: Bar Chart - Plot

title: Categorical Base Plots
text:
Pie Charts: Description

When to Use

Show proportion/percentage of a whole
Display parts-to-whole relationships
Limited to 2-5 categories for clarity

Requirements

One categorical variable
Focus on proportions, not absolute values

Advantages
✅ Intuitive for showing proportions
✅ Familiar to most audiences
✅ Shows relative sizes at a glance
✅ Good for presenting percentages
Limitations
❌ Hard to compare similar-sized slices
❌ Difficult with many categories
❌ Not suitable for precise value comparison
❌ Takes significant space

title: Categorical Base Plots
text:
Pie Chart - Code
# Step 1: Prepare data with percentages
region_data <- df %>%
  count(Region) %>%
  mutate(
    percentage = n / sum(n) * 100,
    label = paste0(Region, "\n", n, " (", round(percentage, 1), "%)")
  )

# Step 2: Create pie chart using coord_polar
ggplot(region_data, aes(x = "", y = n, fill = Region)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity", width = 1) +
  coord_polar("y", start = 0)


# Step 3: Add labels and styling
  geom_text(aes(label = label), 
            position = position_stack(vjust = 0.5), size = 3.5) +
  scale_fill_brewer(palette = "Pastel1") +
  labs(title = "Distribution by Region") +
  theme_void() +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, face = "bold", size = 14))

title: Categorical Base Plots
text: Pie Chart - Plot

title: Categorical Base Plots
text:
Horizontal Bar Chart: Description

When to Use

Display categorical data with long category names
Improve readability by rotating bars
Better for comparing values across categories

Requirements

One categorical variable with long labels
Clear ordering (ascending/descending recommended)

Advantages
✅ Better for long category names
✅ Easier to read values from axis
✅ Natural reading flow
✅ Ordered display improves comparison
Limitations
❌ Takes more horizontal space
❌ Axis labels can still overlap if too many

title: Categorical Base Plots
text:
Horizontal Bar Chart - Code
# Step 1: Calculate frequencies and arrange by count
smoking_data <- df %>%
  count(SmokingStatus) %>%
  mutate(
    percentage = n / sum(n) * 100,
    label = paste0(n, " (", round(percentage, 1), "%)")
  ) %>%
  arrange(n)

# Step 2: Create horizontal bar chart
ggplot(smoking_data, aes(x = reorder(SmokingStatus, n), 
                        y = n, fill = SmokingStatus)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity", width = 0.7) +
  coord_flip()


# Step 3: Add labels and styling
  geom_text(aes(label = label), hjust = -0.1, size = 4) +
  scale_fill_brewer(palette = "Set3") +
  labs(title = "Distribution by Smoking Status", 
       x = "Smoking Status", y = "Frequency") +
  theme(legend.position = "none",
        plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, face = "bold", size = 14))

title: Categorical Base Plots
text: Horizontal Bar Chart - Plot

title: Categorical Base Plots
text:
Donut Charts: Description

When to Use

Show parts-to-whole relationships like pie charts
Better visual appeal than pie charts
Add information in center space

Requirements

One categorical variable (simple)
2-5 categories recommended

Advantages
✅ More modern look than pie charts
✅ Center space displays additional info
✅ Shows proportions effectively
✅ Good for presentations
Limitations
❌ Similar issues as pie charts
❌ Can be cluttered with nested data
❌ Takes more space than bars

title: Categorical Base Plots
text:
Donut Chart - Code
# Step 1: Calculate data
disease_data <- df %>%
  filter(!is.na(ChronicDisease)) %>%
  count(ChronicDisease) %>%
  mutate(
    percentage = n / sum(n) * 100,
    label = paste0(ChronicDisease, "\n", n, " (", round(percentage, 1), "%)")
  )

# Step 2: Create donut shape with coord_polar
ggplot(disease_data, aes(x = 2, y = n, fill = ChronicDisease)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity", width = 1) +
  coord_polar("y", start = 0) +
  xlim(0.5, 2.5)


# Step 3: Add labels and styling
  geom_text(aes(label = label), 
            position = position_stack(vjust = 0.5), size = 3.5) +
  scale_fill_brewer(palette = "Pastel2") +
  labs(title = "Chronic Disease Distribution") +
  theme_void() +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, face = "bold", size = 14))

title: Categorical Base Plots
text: Donut Chart - Plot

title: Categorical Base Plots
text:
Dodged Bar Chart: Description

When to Use

Compare two categorical variables side-by-side
Show relationship between two categorical dimensions
Avoid overlap in bars

Requirements

Two categorical variables
Each with 2-6 categories

Advantages
✅ Easy side-by-side comparison
✅ Clear representation of relationships
✅ Shows both variables simultaneously
✅ No overlap between bars
Limitations
❌ Gets crowded with many categories
❌ Doesn’t show proportions (only counts)
❌ Hard to compare across groups

title: Categorical Base Plots
text:
Dodged Bar Chart - Code
# Step 1: Calculate frequencies
smoking_alcohol_data <- df %>%
  count(SmokingStatus, AlcoholUse) %>%
  group_by(SmokingStatus) %>%
  mutate(
    percentage = n / sum(n) * 100,
    label = paste0(n, "\n(", round(percentage, 1), "%)")
  ) %>%
  ungroup()

# Step 2: Create dodged bar chart
ggplot(smoking_alcohol_data, 
       aes(x = SmokingStatus, y = n, fill = AlcoholUse)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity", position = "dodge", width = 0.7)


# Step 3: Add labels and styling
  geom_text(aes(label = label), 
            position = position_dodge(width = 0.7), vjust = -0.5, size = 3.5) +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("No" = "#66C2A5", "Yes" = "#FC8D62")) +
  labs(title = "Smoking Status by Alcohol Use", 
       x = "Smoking Status", y = "Frequency", fill = "Alcohol Use") +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, face = "bold", size = 14),
        legend.position = "top")

title: Categorical Base Plots
text: Dodged Bar Chart - Plot

title: Categorical Base Plots
text:
Stacked Bar (Count): Description

When to Use

Compare totals across groups
Show composition within each group
Display hierarchical relationships

Requirements

Two categorical variables
Interest in both individual and total counts

Advantages
✅ Shows both composition and totals
✅ Easy to compare group totals
✅ Compact representation
✅ Good for showing contributions
Limitations
❌ Hard to compare middle/top segments
❌ Doesn’t show proportions clearly
❌ Can be misleading with very different group sizes

title: Categorical Base Plots
text:
Stacked Bar (Count) - Code
# Step 1: Calculate frequencies
region_smoking_data <- df %>%
  count(Region, SmokingStatus) %>%
  group_by(Region) %>%
  mutate(
    percentage = n / sum(n) * 100,
    label = ifelse(percentage > 5, 
                   paste0(n, "\n(", round(percentage, 1), "%)"), "")
  ) %>%
  ungroup()

# Step 2: Create stacked bar chart
ggplot(region_smoking_data, 
       aes(x = Region, y = n, fill = SmokingStatus)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity", width = 0.7)


# Step 3: Add labels and styling
  geom_text(aes(label = label), 
            position = position_stack(vjust = 0.5), size = 3,
            color = "white", fontface = "bold") +
  scale_fill_brewer(palette = "Set2") +
  labs(title = "Region by Smoking Status (Count)", x = "Region", y = "Frequency") +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, face = "bold", size = 14),
        legend.position = "top")

title: Categorical Base Plots
text: Stacked Bar (Count) - Plot

title: Categorical Base Plots
text:
Stacked Bar (Proportion): Description

When to Use

Compare proportions/percentages across groups
Show relative composition (0-100%)
Compare distributions when group sizes differ

Requirements

Two categorical variables
Focus on proportions, not absolute counts

Advantages
✅ Easy to compare proportions across groups
✅ Accounts for different group sizes
✅ All bars same height (100%)
✅ Clear compositional comparison
Limitations
❌ Loses information about group sizes
❌ Hard to compare exact proportions
❌ Middle segments still hard to compare

title: Categorical Base Plots
text:
Stacked Bar (Proportion) - Code
# Step 1: Calculate proportions (0-1 scale)
region_smoking_prop <- df %>%
  count(Region, SmokingStatus) %>%
  group_by(Region) %>%
  mutate(
    prop = n / sum(n),
    percentage = prop * 100,
    label = paste0(round(percentage, 1), "%")
  ) %>%
  ungroup()

# Step 2: Create 100% stacked bar chart
ggplot(region_smoking_prop, 
       aes(x = Region, y = prop, fill = SmokingStatus)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity", width = 0.7)


# Step 3: Format and style
  geom_text(aes(label = label), 
            position = position_stack(vjust = 0.5), size = 3.5,
            color = "white", fontface = "bold") +
  scale_y_continuous(labels = scales::percent) +
  scale_fill_brewer(palette = "Set2") +
  labs(title = "Region by Smoking Status (Proportion 0-100%)",
       x = "Region", y = "Proportion", fill = "Smoking Status") +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, face = "bold", size = 14),
        legend.position = "top")

title: Categorical Base Plots
text: Stacked Bar (Proportion) - Plot

title: Categorical Base Plots
text:
Exploded Pie Chart: Description

When to Use

Emphasize one or more categories
Show parts-to-whole with visual emphasis
Highlight important segments

Requirements

One categorical variable with 2-6 categories
Need to emphasize specific slice

Advantages
✅ Draws attention to specific category
✅ More engaging than standard pie
✅ Good for presentations
✅ Shows proportions clearly
Limitations
❌ Can be misleading (emphasized slice appears larger)
❌ Difficult to maintain visual accuracy
❌ Similar issues as pie charts

title: Categorical Base Plots
text:
Exploded Pie Chart - Code
# Step 1: Calculate frequencies and percentages
treatment_data <- df %>%
  count(TreatmentGroup) %>%
  mutate(percentage = n / sum(n) * 100)

labels <- paste0(treatment_data$TreatmentGroup, "\n", 
                 treatment_data$n, " (", 
                 round(treatment_data$percentage, 1), "%)")

# Step 2: Create exploded pie using plotrix
par(mar = c(1, 1, 3, 1))
pie3D(treatment_data$n, 
      labels = labels,
      explode = 0.1,
      col = c("#8DD3C7", "#FFFFB3"))


# Step 3: Add title and formatting
      main = "Treatment Group Distribution (Exploded)",
      cex.main = 1.2,
      labelcex = 1,
      theta = 1.2

title: Categorical Base Plots
text: Exploded Pie Chart - Plot

title: Categorical Base Plots
text:
Triple Donut: Description

When to Use

Show hierarchical or nested categorical relationships
Compare three categories simultaneously
Display proportions at multiple levels

Requirements

Two categorical variables (rings and nested categories)
Interest in hierarchical proportions

Advantages (Concentric)
✅ Shows multiple dimensions compactly
✅ Hierarchical clarity
✅ Visually interesting
✅ Good for storytelling
Limitations (Concentric)
❌ Very difficult to compare rings
❌ Can be visually confusing
❌ Hard to interpret proportions accurately
❌ Limited to 3-4 rings maximum

title: Categorical Base Plots
text:
Triple Donut - Code
# Prepare three separate datasets for ring positions
diabetes_df <- df %>%
  filter(ChronicDisease == "Diabetes" & !is.na(ExerciseFreq)) %>%
  count(ExerciseFreq) %>%
  mutate(disease = "Diabetes", x = 0.5)

htn_df <- df %>%
  filter(ChronicDisease == "Hypertension" & !is.na(ExerciseFreq)) %>%
  count(ExerciseFreq) %>%
  mutate(disease = "Hypertension", x = 0.7)

heart_df <- df %>%
  filter(ChronicDisease == "Heart Disease" & !is.na(ExerciseFreq)) %>%
  count(ExerciseFreq) %>%
  mutate(disease = "Heart Disease", x = 0.9)

combined <- bind_rows(diabetes_df, htn_df, heart_df)

# Create three bars at different positions
ggplot(combined, aes(fill = ExerciseFreq, y = n)) +
  geom_bar(data = filter(combined, disease == "Diabetes"),
           aes(x = 0.5), stat = "identity", width = 0.2, 
           color = "white", size = 0.5) +
  geom_bar(data = filter(combined, disease == "Hypertension"),
           aes(x = 0.7), stat = "identity", width = 0.2,
           color = "white", size = 0.5) +
  geom_bar(data = filter(combined, disease == "Heart Disease"),
           aes(x = 0.9), stat = "identity", width = 0.2,
           color = "white", size = 0.5)


# Convert to polar and style
+ coord_polar(theta = "y") +
  xlim(c(0.2, 1.0)) +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("Daily" = "#66BB6A",
                               "3-5 times/week" = "#90CAF9",
                               "1-2 times/week" = "#F48FB1")) +
  labs(title = "Exercise Frequency by Chronic Disease",
       fill = "Exercise") +
  theme_void() +
  theme(plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, face = "bold", size = 14),
        legend.position = "right")

title: Categorical Base Plots
text: Triple Donut - Plot

title: Categorical Base Plots
text:
Mosaic Plot: Description

When to Use

Display relationships between 2+ categorical variables
Show proportions in contingency tables
Identify associations between variables

Requirements

Multiple categorical variables (2-4 typically)
Can handle unbalanced data

How to Interpret

Tile width: First variable proportion
Tile height: Second variable conditional proportion
Tile area: Combined proportion
Empty space: Cells with low frequency
Color intensity: Strength of association

Advantages
✅ Shows multi-dimensional relationships
✅ Displays proportions simultaneously
✅ Highlights sparse cells
✅ Visual independence test

title: Categorical Base Plots
text:
Mosaic Plot - Code
# Step 1: Prepare data and remove NAs
mosaic_data <- df %>%
  filter(!is.na(AlcoholUse)) %>%
  select(TreatmentGroup, Gender, SmokingStatus, AlcoholUse)

# Create contingency table
mosaic_table <- xtabs(~ TreatmentGroup + Gender + 
                        SmokingStatus + AlcoholUse, 
                      data = mosaic_data)

# Step 2: Create mosaic plot using vcd package
mosaic(mosaic_table,
       main = "Mosaic Plot: 4-way Relationship",
       highlighting = "AlcoholUse",
       highlighting_fill = c("#8DD3C7", "#FB8072"),
       direction = c("v", "v", "h", "h"))


# Step 3: Add labels and formatting
       spacing = spacing_highlighting,
       labeling = labeling_border(rot_labels = c(45, 0, 0, 0),
                                  just_labels = c("right", "center", 
                                                  "center", "center"),
                                  varnames = TRUE,
                                  abbreviate_labs = TRUE)

title: Categorical Base Plots
text: Mosaic Plot - Output

title: Categorical Base Plots
text:
Choosing the Right Plot

Single Variable
Bar → Pie → Horizontal Bar → Donut
Two Variables
Dodged → Stacked Count → Stacked Proportion
Complex/Hierarchical
Exploded Pie → Triple Donut → Mosaic
Key Decision Points

How many variables? (1, 2, 3+)
What’s your message? (counts vs proportions)
Who’s the audience? (technical vs general)
Show relationships or distributions?

title: Categorical Base Plots
text:
Best Practices

Do’s ✅

Keep labels clear and complete
Use color meaningfully (not randomly)
Order categories logically
Include percentages with counts
Choose the simplest effective plot
Test readability at presentation size

Don’ts ❌

Avoid 3D effects (distort perception)
Don’t use too many colors
Avoid misleading axis scales
Don’t overcrowd with too many categories
Never remove axis labels
Don’t use pie charts for 5+ categories

title: Exporting plots
text: Exporting plots from R can be done in several ways, depending on the desired output format and quality. Here are some common methods to export plots: 1. Using R’s built-in functions: - png(), jpeg(), tiff(), bmp(): These functions allow you to save plots in various raster formats. You can specify the filename, width, height, and resolution. R      png("plot.png", width=800, height=600)      plot(x, y)      dev.off() - pdf(): This function saves plots in PDF format, which is vector-based and suitable for high-quality prints. R      pdf("plot.pdf", width=8, height=6)      plot(x, y)      dev.off() - svg(): This function saves plots in SVG format, which is also vector-based and ideal for web use. R      svg("plot.svg", width=8, height=6)      plot(x, y)      dev.off()

title: Navigating the Decision Tree
section: Choosing the Right Visualization for Your Data
text:
Choosing the Right Visualization for Your Data
A Practical Framework Based on Analytical Goals

title: Navigating the Decision Tree
text:
Your Roadmap for Visualization Selection


Identify Your Data Type

What kind of data do you have? (Numeric, Categorical, Temporal, etc.)

Define Your Analytical Goal

What do you want to communicate? (Compare, Distribute, Show Relationships, etc.)

Select the Appropriate Chart

What visualization best achieves your goal?

title: Navigating the Decision Tree
text:
Color-Coded Framework









Goal
Symbol
Question
Purpose




Distribution
●
“What’s the spread?”
Show data spread, shape, outliers


Correlation
●
“How do things relate?”
Show relationships between variables


Ranking
●
“What’s the order?”
Compare values in order


Part of Whole
●
“What’s the composition?”
Show proportions/percentages


Evolution
●
“How does it change over time?”
Track trends and changes


Maps
●
“Where is it located?”
Geographic/spatial distribution


Flow
●
“How does it move?”
Movement, transitions, journeys

title: Navigating the Decision Tree
section: Quick Reference - What Each Color Means
text:
Quick Reference - What Each Color Means

● Gold/Yellow = Distribution - Shows data spread, frequency, shape, outliers
● Blue = Correlation - Shows relationships, associations between variables
● Green = Ranking - Shows order, comparison of values, top/bottom
● Red/Salmon = Part of Whole - Shows composition, proportions, percentages
● Light Blue = Evolution - Shows trends, changes over time, trajectories
● Purple = Maps - Shows geographic/spatial distribution, location-based data
● Pink/Tan = Flow - Shows movement, transitions, journeys, hierarchies

Tip: When you see a colored dot next to a chart name, it tells you what analytical goal that chart serves best!

title: Navigating the Decision Tree
text:
The 6 Data Type Categories








Data Type
Definition
Examples




Numeric
Continuous measurements
Age, weight, blood pressure, lab values


Categoric
Discrete categories/groups
Gender, disease status, treatment type


Ordinal
Ordered categories
Likert scale, tumor stages, severity levels


Time Series
Temporal/chronological data
Monthly incidence, patient vitals over time


Relational
Connections/networks
Patient pathways, disease networks


Map
Geographic/spatial data
Regional disease rates, location coordinates

title: Navigating the Decision Tree
text:
How Variables Combine
SINGLE VARIABLE
├── Numeric → Histogram, Density, Boxplot
├── Categoric → Bar, Pie, Lollipop
├── Ordinal → Ordered Bar, Cumulative Frequency
├── Time Series → Line, Area
├── Map → Choropleth, Bubble Map
└── Relational → Network Graph

BIVARIATE (TWO VARIABLES)
├── Numeric × Numeric → Scatter, Hexbin, Bubble
├── Numeric × Categoric → Boxplot, Violin, Grouped Bar
├── Categoric × Categoric → Grouped/Stacked Bar, Mosaic, Heatmap
├── Time Series × Numeric → Multi-line, Stacked Area
├── Time Series × Categoric → Faceted Line, Interaction Plot
└── Any + Relational → Sankey, Chord

MULTIVARIATE (3+ VARIABLES)
├── Numeric × Numeric × Numeric → Bubble, Faceted Scatter
├── Numeric × Multiple Categoric → Faceted Box/Violin, Interaction
├── Multiple Categoric × Multiple Categoric → Sankey, Sunburst, Treemap
├── Time Series × Multiple Variables → Ridgeline, Faceted Line
└── Hierarchical → Treemap, Sunburst, Hierarchical Edge Bundling

title: Navigating the Decision Tree
text:
● Distribution | ● Ranking | ● Part of Whole
Chart Options:

Bar Chart ● (counts/frequencies)
Lollipop Chart ● (alternative to bar, especially for long lists)
Cleveland Dot Plot ● (ranked comparison)
Pie Chart ● (≤5 categories only, part-to-whole)
Doughnut Chart ● (like pie, better labels)
Circular Bar Plot ● (aesthetic alternative)

Healthcare Examples:

Disease prevalence by state
Hospitalization by insurance type
Comorbidity frequency distribution

Decision Guide:

Few categories (<5) and need part-of-whole → Pie/Doughnut
Few-moderate categories → Bar chart (horizontal if long names)
Many categories (>8) → Lollipop or Cleveland dot
Need ranking emphasis → Ordered bar or lollipop

title: Navigating the Decision Tree
text:
● Distribution | ● Part of Whole (Ordered)
Chart Options:

Ordered Bar Chart ● (maintain categorical order)
Ordered Dot Plot ●
Cumulative Frequency Plot ● (especially for Likert scales)
Frequency Polygon ● (smooth trend)

Healthcare Examples:

Patient satisfaction (Likert: 1=Very Unsatisfied to 5=Very Satisfied)
Tumor stages frequency (Stage I → II → III → IV)
Pain severity distribution (None → Mild → Moderate → Severe)
Risk level counts (Low → Medium → High)

Decision Guide:

Likert scales → Stacked ordered bar or cumulative frequency
Natural progression (stages, severity) → Maintain order on axis
Show accumulation → Cumulative frequency plot
Compare between groups → Grouped ordered bar

title: Navigating the Decision Tree
text:
● Distribution
Chart Options:

Histogram ● (shows bin structure, distribution shape)
Density Plot ● (smooth, continuous estimate)
Boxplot ● (summary: median, quartiles, outliers)
Violin Plot ● (distribution + boxplot combined)
Dot/Strip Plot ● (individual points, best for small n)

Healthcare Examples:

Age distribution in cohort
Blood pressure measurements in population
Lab values (HbA1c, cholesterol, creatinine)
Hospital length of stay

Decision Guide:



Scenario
Best Choice
Why




n < 20
Dot/Strip plot
See every point


n = 20-100
Histogram + Boxplot
Balance detail & summary


n > 100
Density plot
Smooth, reduces noise


Want outliers
Boxplot
Shows extreme values clearly


Want shape details
Violin plot
Shows multimodality, skewness

title: Navigating the Decision Tree
text:
● Evolution
Chart Options:

Line Chart ● (standard for continuous time data)
Area Chart ● (emphasizes magnitude/volume)
Streamgraph ● (stacked area with flowing theme)

Healthcare Examples:

Disease incidence trends over years
Hospital admission rates monthly
COVID-19 case counts by week
Patient vital signs during hospitalization

Decision Guide:

Single series, continuous time → Line chart
Show cumulative volume → Area chart
Multiple series, show total → Stacked area
Sparse time points → Line chart with markers

title: Navigating the Decision Tree
text:
● Maps
Chart Options:

Choropleth Map ● (color-coded by region)
Bubble Map ● (circles sized by value)
Heat Map ● (geographic intensity)
Dot Map ● (point locations)

Healthcare Examples:

Regional disease rates (e.g., TB incidence by state in India)
Hospital bed density by district
Maternal mortality ratios by region
Vaccination coverage by area

Decision Guide:

Show rate/percentage by region → Choropleth
Show absolute counts by location → Bubble map
Show intensity/density → Heat map
Specific point locations matter → Dot map

title: Navigating the Decision Tree
text:
● Correlation | ● Distribution
Chart Options:

Scatter Plot ● (relationship between two continuous variables)
Hexbin Plot ● (2D histogram for dense data)
2D Density Plot ● (contour or heatmap of overlapping points)
Bubble Plot ● (3rd variable via size or color)

Healthcare Examples:

Age vs BMI (body mass relationship)
HbA1c vs Blood Glucose (glycemic control markers)
Creatinine vs eGFR (kidney function)
Systolic vs Diastolic Blood Pressure

Decision Guide:



Scenario
Best Choice




Moderate sample, clear pattern
Scatter plot


Large n, lots of overplotting
Hexbin or 2D density


Want 3rd variable shown
Bubble (size) or color gradient


Focused region interest
Zoomed scatter with annotations

title: Navigating the Decision Tree
text:
● Distribution | ● Correlation (Comparison)
Chart Options:

Boxplot ● (median, quartiles, outliers by group)
Violin Plot ● (distribution shape by group)
Jittered Dot/Strip/Beeswarm Plot ● (individual points by group)
Bar Chart with Error Bars ● (mean/median ± SD/IQR)
Cleveland Dot Plot ● (ranked group means)

Healthcare Examples:

HbA1c levels across treatment arms
BMI by disease status (healthy vs diabetic vs obese)
Blood pressure by gender
Hospital length of stay by admission type

Decision Guide:



Sample Size
Distribution Focus
Summary Focus




n < 30
Dot/Strip + Boxplot
Not recommended


n = 30-100
Violin or Boxplot
Bar with error bars


n > 100
Violin plot
Density overlay + mean line


Outliers matter
Boxplot + jitter
Always show


Group ranking focus
Ranked dots
Lollipop chart

title: Navigating the Decision Tree
text:
● Correlation (Probability)
Chart Options:

Logistic Regression Curve ● (smooth probability line)
Density Overlay ● (stacked densities by category)
Grouped Histogram/Density ● (overlapping distributions)

Healthcare Examples:

Disease presence/absence across age ranges
Treatment response (yes/no) by baseline score
Adverse event (yes/no) by medication dose
Mortality (yes/no) by APACHE score

Visualization:

X-axis: Numeric predictor (age, score, dose)
Y-axis: Probability or proportion
Two groups shown as overlapping curves or stacked

title: Navigating the Decision Tree
section: ● Distribution | ● Ranking | ● Part of Whole | ● Correlation
text:
● Distribution | ● Ranking | ● Part of Whole | ● Correlation
Chart Options:

Grouped Bar Chart ● (side-by-side comparison)
Dodged Bar Chart ● (similar to grouped)
Stacked Bar Chart ● (shows totals + composition)
Stacked Bar (Proportional) ● (percentage/100% stacked)
Mosaic Plot ● (area ∝ frequency, shows association)
Heatmap ● (color intensity for cell frequencies)

Healthcare Examples:

Gender vs Disease status (M/F vs HIV+/HIV-)
Treatment arm vs Adverse event (Drug A/B vs AE Yes/No)
Hospital site vs Patient outcome (Site 1-3 vs Recovered/Died)
Risk level by comorbidity count

Decision Guide:



Goal
Best Chart




Compare totals & subgroups
Grouped bar


Show composition per category
Stacked bar


Show percentages only
Stacked bar (proportional)


Detect association strength
Mosaic or heatmap


Many categories, dense
Heatmap with color gradient

title: Navigating the Decision Tree
text:
● Distribution (Ordered)
Chart Options:

Ordered Boxplot ● (boxplot by ordinal groups, maintaining order)
Ordered Violin Plot ● (violin by ordinal groups)
Ordered Jittered Points ● (points by group, groups ordered)

Healthcare Examples:

Medication efficacy vs dose level (Low/Medium/High)
Lab value vs disease severity (Stage I-IV)
Pain score vs treatment intensity (Mild/Moderate/Severe)
Functional status vs age group (Young/Middle/Elderly)

Key Point:

Always maintain explicit ordering on axis
Example: Severity I → II → III → IV (not random order)

title: Navigating the Decision Tree
text:
● Evolution | ● Correlation (Trend)
Chart Options:

Line Chart ● (single series over time)
Multi-line Chart ● (multiple series overlay)
Area Chart ● (cumulative volume over time)
Stacked Area Chart ● (composition over time)
Connected Scatter ● (if sparse time points)

Healthcare Examples:

Disease incidence trends over years (single disease)
Patient vital signs over hospital stay (temperature, BP, HR)
Medication effectiveness over weeks (Drug A vs B)
Mortality rates over decades by region

Decision Guide:

Single series → Line chart
Few series (2-3) to compare → Multi-line chart
Many series, want to show total → Stacked area
Series showing parts of whole → Stacked area
Sparse measurements → Line with markers or connected scatter

title: Navigating the Decision Tree
text:
● Evolution (By Group) | ● Correlation (Group Comparison)
Chart Options:

Grouped Line Chart ● (separate lines for each group)
Faceted Line Chart ● (separate subplots per group)
Grouped Area Chart ● (stacked or overlapping)
Interaction Plot ● (lines intersecting showing interaction)
Ribbon Chart ● (flowing bands representing groups)

Healthcare Examples:

Mortality rate trends (gender comparison: M vs F)
Hospital admission trends by institution (5-year follow-up)
Drug effectiveness over time by treatment arm
Complication rates by age group over study period

Decision Guide:

Few groups (2-3) → Multi-line chart
Many groups (5+) → Faceted line plots
Want to show total + groups → Stacked area
Interaction patterns matter → Interaction plot (lines cross)
Space constraints → Faceting better than overlapping

title: Navigating the Decision Tree
text:
● Distribution (Ordered) | ● Part of Whole (Ordered)
Chart Options:

Ordered Grouped Bar Chart ● (bars by category, groups ordered)
Ordered Stacked Bar ● (stacked, ordinal categories in order)
Faceted Ordered Bar ● (subplots maintaining order)

Healthcare Examples:

Patient satisfaction (Likert: 1-5) by hospital ward
Pain severity (None/Mild/Moderate/Severe) by treatment type
Risk level (Low/Med/High) by comorbidity count
Functional status by treatment arm

Key Point:

Maintain ordinal ordering on one axis
Example: Satisfaction scale always: 1 → 2 → 3 → 4 → 5

title: Navigating the Decision Tree
text:
3+ Continuous Variables | ● Correlation
Chart Options:

Bubble Plot ● (x, y, size = 3rd; color/opacity = 4th)
Faceted Scatter ● (scatter by groups, multiple subplots)
3D Scatter (NOT recommended: distorts perception)

Healthcare Examples:

Age vs BMI (size=cholesterol, color=treatment arm)
HbA1c vs glucose (size=insulin, faceted by gender)
Systolic vs diastolic BP (colored by smoking status)

Decision Guide:

3 variables → Bubble plot (x, y, size)
4 variables → Bubble + color
5+ variables → Multiple faceted plots (don’t try to cram)

title: Navigating the Decision Tree
text:
● Correlation Matrix
Chart Options:

Correlation Matrix ● (numeric table of coefficients)
Correlogram ● (heatmap with color intensity = correlation strength)
Scatter Plot Matrix ● (pairwise scatter plots)

Healthcare Examples:

Lab inter-correlations: glucose, insulin, triglycerides, HDL, LDL
Vital signs correlations: BP, HR, RR, O2 saturation, temperature
Biomarker relationships in cohort study

Visualization:

Color intensity (warm = positive, cool = negative)
Cell size may represent correlation strength
Diagonal typically = 1.0 (variable with itself)

title: Navigating the Decision Tree
text:
● Distribution (Faceted) | ● Correlation (Interaction)
Chart Options:

Faceted Boxplot/Violin ● (boxplot per group, subplots for 3rd variable)
Interaction Plot ● (lines connecting means by two factors)
Faceted Scatter + regression lines ● (by groups)

Healthcare Examples:

HbA1c by treatment type, faceted by gender (4 subplots: 2 treat × 2 gender)
Lab values by disease status, colored by age group
Drug efficacy by dose level, faceted by patient comorbidity

Visualization Strategy:

Primary grouping on axis
Secondary grouping via facets or colors
Show interactions: do lines cross? Do patterns differ?

title: Navigating the Decision Tree
text:
● Evolution (Advanced) | ● Distribution (Temporal)
Chart Options:

Multi-line Chart with Faceting ● (separate subplots per group)
Ridgeline Plot ● (distribution by group, stacked vertically)
Slope Chart ● (start → end values, multiple series)
Animated Time Series ● (interactive exploration)

Healthcare Examples:

Disease incidence over years, separate lines by region (5 regions)
Patient vitals during admission, faceted by treatment arm
Hospital census by time, colored by department

Decision Guide:

Multiple time series + groups → Faceted multi-line
Distribution evolution over time → Ridgeline plot
Show change from start to end → Slope chart

title: Navigating the Decision Tree
text:
● Flow | ● Part of Whole (Hierarchical)
Chart Options:

Sankey Diagram ● (flow from one category to another)
Alluvial Diagram ● (similar to Sankey, broader flows)
Treemap ● (nested rectangles for hierarchy)
Sunburst Chart ● (nested circles/rings for hierarchy)

Healthcare Examples:

Sankey: Patient flow (admission → diagnostic → treatment → discharge)
Alluvial: Disease progression stages (diagnosis → worsening/improvement → outcome)
Treemap: Hospital structure (Region → Hospital → Department → Ward)
Sunburst: Disease classification (Category → Subcategory → Specific condition)

Decision Guide:

Flow/transition/journey → Sankey or Alluvial
Nested hierarchy/parts → Treemap or Sunburst

title: Navigating the Decision Tree
text:
● Flow | ● Correlation (Connections)
Chart Options:

Sankey Diagram ● (directional flows between nodes)
Chord Diagram ● (bi-directional relationships, circular)
Network Graph ● (nodes + edges, force-directed layout)
Arc Diagram ● (nodes in line, arcs show connections)

Healthcare Examples:

Sankey: Patient journeys through clinic system
Chord: Disease co-occurrence patterns (patient network)
Network: Hospital referral patterns (which hospitals refer to which)
Arc: Comorbidity networks (which diseases co-occur)

Visualization:

Nodes = entities (patients, diseases, hospitals)
Edges/arcs/flows = relationships (referral, co-occurrence)

title: Navigating the Decision Tree
text:
● Part of Whole | ● Flow
Chart Options:

Treemap ● (nested rectangles, size ∝ value)
Sunburst Chart ● (nested circles, size ∝ value)
Hierarchical Edge Bundling ● (connections in hierarchy)

Healthcare Examples:

Treemap: Hospital admissions by Region → State → Hospital → Department (size = admission count)
Sunburst: Disease classification by Category → Subcategory → Specific condition → ICD code
Hierarchical Edge Bundling: Referral patterns between hospitals at different levels

Decision Guide:

Static hierarchy focus → Treemap
Want circular aesthetic → Sunburst
Complex relationships in hierarchy → Hierarchical edge bundling

title: Navigating the Decision Tree
text:
● Flow | ● Part of Whole
Waterfall Chart

Shows cumulative effect of sequential positive/negative values
Healthcare Example: Patient survival from enrollment → screening loss → randomization → completion

Start: 1000 enrolled
Drop: -50 screening failures
Drop: -30 withdrawn consent
End: 920 completed


Funnel Chart

Stages in a process, showing attrition at each step
Healthcare Example: Hospital admission pipeline

Emergency triage: 500
Admitted: 400 (20% filtered out)
Discharged: 350 (12.5% transferred)
Readmitted: 30 (8.6% recurrent)

title: Navigating the Decision Tree
text:
● Evolution (Advanced) | ● Distribution (Temporal)
Streamgraph

Stacked area with flowing, organic theme
Example: Emergency admissions over time, stacked by department

Total volume trends visible + department composition


Calendar Heatmap

Daily/weekly patterns across entire year
Example: Hospital occupancy by day of week

Darker = higher occupancy
Pattern reveals peak days/seasons


Frequency Polygon

Line connecting histogram bins
Example: Age distribution comparison between cohorts

Multiple overlaid frequency polygons

title: Navigating the Decision Tree
text:
● Distribution (Text) | ● Correlation (Networks)
Word Cloud

Text frequency visualization, size = occurrence
Limitation: More visual impact than analytic precision
Healthcare Use: Patient feedback themes, common symptoms

Arc Diagram

Network relationships with improved readability over hairball graphs
Example: Disease comorbidity network, cleaner than typical network graph

Hierarchical Edge Bundling

Complex relationship networks with hierarchy
Example: Referral patterns between hospitals (different organizational levels)

title: Navigating the Decision Tree
section: Scenario: “Quarterly revenue by product category over 2 years”
text:
Scenario: “Quarterly revenue by product category over 2 years”
Step 1: Identify Data Type

Time component: Quarterly (Time Series)
Product component: Multiple categories (Categoric)
Revenue component: Continuous (Numeric)
Combined: Time Series + Categoric + Numeric

Step 2: Define Analytical Goal

Primary: ● Evolution (how revenue changes over time)
Secondary: ● Correlation (how categories compare)

Step 3: Chart Options









Option
Chart Type
Pros
Cons




A
Multi-line chart ●
Clear trend per product
Can be cluttered if >5 products


B
Stacked area ●
Show total + composition
Hard to compare individual products


C
Faceted line charts ●
Each product clear
Uses more space


D
Grouped bar chart ●
Periodic view (snapshot)
Less sense of continuous trend

title: Navigating the Decision Tree
section: Scenario: “HbA1c levels across three treatment arms over 12 months”
text:
Scenario: “HbA1c levels across three treatment arms over 12 months”
Step 1: Identify Data Type

Time component: Baseline, 6mo, 12mo (Time Series - discrete)
Group component: 3 treatment arms (Categoric)
Outcome component: HbA1c values (Numeric)
Combined: Time Series + Categoric + Numeric

Step 2: Define Analytical Goal

Primary: ● Evolution (trajectories over follow-up)
Secondary: ● Correlation (do arms differ?)
Tertiary: ● Distribution (spread within each arm at each timepoint)

Step 3: Chart Options








Option
Chart Type
Visualization




A
Multi-line ± CI ●
One line per arm, shaded confidence bands


B
Faceted violin plots ●
3 subplots (one per arm), violin at each timepoint


C
Spaghetti plot ●
Individual patient trajectories, color-coded by arm


D
Interaction plot ●
Means connected by lines, x-axis = timepoint

title: Navigating the Decision Tree
section: Scenario: “Top 10 competitors’ market share over 5 years by region”
text:
Scenario: “Top 10 competitors’ market share over 5 years by region”
Step 1: Identify Data Type

Time: Years (Time Series)
Competitors: 10 categories (Categoric)
Regions: Multiple regions (Categoric)
Market share: Percentage (Numeric)
Dimensions: 4 (too many for single plot!)

Step 2: Define Analytical Goal

● Evolution (trends over time)
● Ranking (who’s leading?)
● Correlation (how do regions differ?)
● Composition (what % of total?)

Step 3: Chart Options







Option
Approach




A
Stacked area per region (faceted: 3-5 subplots) ● ●


B
Grouped multi-line (each region = different color) ●


C
Animated bar chart (top 10 race by region) ● ●


D
Interactive dashboard (toggle region) ●



Decision:

Best static option: Faceted stacked area (shows time, composition, region comparison)
Best interactive: Animated bar or dashboard

title: Navigating the Decision Tree
text:
❌ What NOT to Do
❌ Pie charts with 10+ categories

Why? Human perception fails with small angles
Solution: Use bar chart ●, lollipop ●, or split into multiple pies

❌ 3D charts

Why? Perspective distorts data perception (3D cone/pyramid/sphere)
Solution: Stick to 2D representations

❌ Dual-axis charts

Why? Can mislead by manipulating axis scales
Solution: Use faceting or separate plots instead

❌ Wrong color coding

Why? Color should reinforce analytical goal (not random aesthetic)
Solution: Sequential colors for magnitude, categorical colors for groups

❌ Overplotting (overlapping points)

Why? Can’t see density or exact position
Solution: Use transparency (alpha), jitter, hexbin ●, or density plots ●

❌ Stacked bars for detailed comparison

Why? Only first and last categories are easy to compare
Solution: Use grouped bar ● or faceting for detailed comparison

❌ Too many dimensions on one plot

Why? Cognitive overload, hard to extract insight
Solution: Split into multiple focused visualizations

text:
Apply What You’ve Learned
Scenario 1: Employee Satisfaction
Question: Show employee satisfaction scores (Likert 1-5) across hospital departments, comparing before/after intervention

What data types are present?

Recommend chart type(s)

title: Navigating the Decision Tree
text:
Core Principles for Effective Visualization
✅ Always start with your analytical goal - What question are you answering? (distribute, compare, rank, relate, etc.)
✅ Data types narrow your options significantly - Numeric vs Categoric vs Ordinal vs Temporal vs Spatial
✅ Multiple valid charts may exist—choose based on audience & context - Scientist ≠ Executive ≠ Patient communication
✅ Use color strategically to support your analytical goal - Sequential for magnitude, categorical for groups, diverging for contrasts
✅ Simplicity trumps complexity; avoid unnecessary dimensions - If 3D doesn’t add insight, keep it 2D - If faceting helps clarity, use it
✅ When in doubt, check data-to-viz.com or reference examples - Don’t reinvent the wheel; learn from established best practices
✅ Practice makes perfect—iterate on visualizations - First draft rarely optimal; refine based on feedback
