title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 3
text:
Module 3 Overview
Previously: - Module 1: Foundations & Geoms - Module 2: Aesthetics & Faceting & Themes
This Module: - Color palettes & accessibility - paletteer package - Scale functions (manual, discrete, continuous, gradient) - Custom theme creation with theme() - element_text(), element_line(), element_rect(), element_blank() - Legend management

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 3
text:
Setup


Code
library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)
library(tidyr)
library(readxl)
library(ggthemes)
library(paletteer)  # For extensive color palettes
library(patchwork)  # For combining plots

# Load data
bp_data <- read_excel("../../data/PublicHealth_BP_Dataset.xlsx") %>%
  mutate(
    SysBP_Change = SysBP_6m - SysBP_0m,
    AgeGroup = cut(Age, breaks = c(0, 30, 50, 65, 100),
                   labels = c("18-30", "31-50", "51-65", "65+")),
    Hypertension_Baseline = ifelse(SysBP_0m >= 140 | DiaBP_0m >= 90, 
                                   "Hypertensive", "Normal"),
    BMI_Category = cut(BMI, breaks = c(0, 18.5, 25, 30, 100),
                       labels = c("Underweight", "Normal", "Overweight", "Obese"))
  )

region_summary <- bp_data %>%
  group_by(Region) %>%
  summarise(Mean_SysBP = mean(SysBP_0m), N = n(), .groups = "drop")

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 3
text:
Color Theory Basics


Hue: The color itself (red, blue, green)
Saturation: Intensity/purity of color
Luminance: Brightness/lightness
Contrast: Difference between colors



Key principles: - Use color purposefully, not decoratively - Ensure sufficient contrast for readability - Consider colorblind accessibility (~8% of males, ~0.5% of females) - Limit number of colors (typically ≤7 for categorical data)

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 3
text:
scale_color_brewer() - ColorBrewer Palettes




Code
ggplot(bp_data, 
       aes(x = Age, y = SysBP_0m,
           color = Region)) +
  geom_point(size = 3, alpha = 0.7) +
  scale_color_brewer(palette = "Set2") +
  theme_minimal()



Types: Sequential, Diverging, Qualitative
Use: Professional, well-tested color combinations

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 3
text:
Colorblind-Friendly: Viridis




Code
ggplot(bp_data, 
       aes(x = BMI, y = Cholesterol,
           color = SysBP_0m)) +
  geom_point(size = 3, alpha = 0.7) +
  scale_color_viridis_c(option = "plasma") +
  theme_minimal()



Options: “viridis”, “magma”, “plasma”, “inferno”, “cividis”
Advantages: Colorblind-safe, perceptually uniform, prints well in B&W

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 3
text:
Viridis for Discrete Variables




Code
ggplot(bp_data, 
       aes(x = Age, y = SysBP_0m,
           color = Region)) +
  geom_point(size = 3, alpha = 0.7) +
  scale_color_viridis_d(option = "viridis") +
  theme_minimal()



**_d** for discrete, **_c** for continuous
Always prefer colorblind-friendly palettes!

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 3
text:
paletteer Package - Universal Access


Access to 2500+ color palettes from various R packages
Unified interface for all palette packages
Includes: RColorBrewer, viridis, ggsci, wesanderson, and many more
Easy to browse and apply




Code
library(paletteer)

# Preview available palettes
# paletteer_d_names  # Discrete palettes
# paletteer_c_names  # Continuous palettes

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 3
text:
paletteer: Discrete Palettes




Code
ggplot(bp_data, 
       aes(x = AgeGroup, y = SysBP_0m,
           fill = TreatmentGroup)) +
  geom_boxplot(alpha = 0.8) +
  scale_fill_paletteer_d(
    "ggsci::nrc_npg") +
  theme_minimal()



Format: "package::palette_name"
Explore with: paletteer_d_names

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 3
text:
paletteer: Continuous Palettes




Code
ggplot(bp_data, 
       aes(x = Age, y = BMI,
           color = Cholesterol)) +
  geom_point(size = 3, alpha = 0.7) +
  scale_color_paletteer_c(
    "viridis::mako") +
  theme_minimal()



Beautiful gradients for continuous variables
Explore with: paletteer_c_names

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 3
text:
Best Practices for Color


Use color purposefully - not just for decoration
Prefer colorblind-safe palettes - viridis, ColorBrewer, paletteer curated sets
Limit colors - typically ≤7 distinct colors for categorical
Use redundant encoding - combine color with shape, pattern, or position
Ensure contrast - especially for text and important distinctions
Consider grayscale - will it work if printed in black & white?
Cultural context - red/green may have different meanings
Test with target audience - especially for accessibility needs

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 3
text:
Scale System Overview


Scales control how data values map to visual properties
Every aesthetic has an associated scale
Format: scale_<aesthetic>_<type>()

aesthetic: color, fill, x, y, size, shape, alpha
type: continuous, discrete, manual, gradient, brewer, viridis

Scales control: breaks, limits, labels, transformations




Code
scale_color_manual(values = c("red", "blue"))
scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(0, 100, 20))

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 3
text:
scale_color_manual(): Custom Colors




Code
ggplot(bp_data, 
       aes(x = Age, y = SysBP_0m,
           color = TreatmentGroup)) +
  geom_point(size = 3, alpha = 0.7) +
  scale_color_manual(
    values = c("Control" = "steelblue",
               "Intervention" = "darkred"),
    name = "Treatment")



Use for: Exact control over categorical colors
Can use named colors or hex codes

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 3
text:
scale_fill_manual(): Custom Fills




Code
ggplot(region_summary, 
       aes(x = reorder(Region, Mean_SysBP), 
           y = Mean_SysBP, fill = Region)) +
  geom_col() +
  scale_fill_manual(
    values = c("North" = "lightblue",
               "South" = "coral",
               "East" = "lightgreen",
               "West" = "plum"))

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 3
text:
scale_color_gradient(): Two-Color Gradient




Code
ggplot(bp_data, 
       aes(x = Age, y = BMI,
           color = SysBP_0m)) +
  geom_point(size = 3, alpha = 0.7) +
  scale_color_gradient(
    low = "yellow", high = "darkred",
    name = "Systolic BP")



Use for: Continuous variables with low-to-high progression

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 3
text:
scale_color_gradient2(): Diverging Gradient




Code
ggplot(bp_data, 
       aes(x = Age, y = BMI,
           color = SysBP_Change)) +
  geom_point(size = 3, alpha = 0.7) +
  scale_color_gradient2(
    low = "blue", mid = "white", 
    high = "red",
    midpoint = 0,
    name = "BP Change")



Use for: Data with meaningful midpoint (zero, mean)
Perfect for showing increases vs decreases

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 3
text:
scale_x_continuous(): Axis Control




Code
ggplot(bp_data, 
       aes(x = Age, y = SysBP_0m)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.5) +
  scale_x_continuous(
    breaks = seq(20, 80, by = 10),
    limits = c(15, 85),
    labels = paste0(seq(20, 80, 10), " yrs"),
    name = "Patient Age")



Controls: breaks (tick marks), limits (range), labels, name

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 3
text:
scale_x_discrete(): Reordering Categories




Code
ggplot(region_summary, 
       aes(x = Region, y = Mean_SysBP,
           fill = Region)) +
  geom_col() +
  scale_x_discrete(
    limits = c("West", "North", 
               "South", "East"),
    labels = c("Western", "Northern",
               "Southern", "Eastern"))



Use for: Custom order and labels for categorical data

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 3
text:
theme() Function Anatomy
The theme() function customizes non-data plot elements:


Element functions:

element_text() - Text elements (labels, titles, axis text)
element_line() - Line elements (axis lines, grid lines)
element_rect() - Rectangle elements (backgrounds, borders)
element_blank() - Remove elements completely





Code
theme(
  axis.title = element_text(size = 14, face = "bold"),
  panel.grid = element_line(color = "gray80")
)

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 3
text:
element_text(): Text Customization




Code
ggplot(bp_data, 
       aes(x = Region, y = SysBP_0m,
           fill = Region)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    axis.title = element_text(
      size = 16, face = "bold",
      color = "darkblue"),
    axis.text = element_text(
      size = 12, color = "gray30"),
    plot.title = element_text(
      size = 20, face = "bold",
      hjust = 0.5)
  )

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 3
text:
Using Serif Fonts




Code
ggplot(bp_data, 
       aes(x = Age, y = SysBP_0m)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.5, color = "darkred") +
  labs(title = "Systolic BP by Age") +
  theme_classic() +
  theme(
    text = element_text(
      family = "serif",
      size = 14),
    plot.title = element_text(
      family = "serif",
      size = 18, face = "bold")
  )



Common families: “serif”, “sans”, “mono”
Great for academic publications

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 3
text:
element_line(): Line Customization




Code
ggplot(bp_data, 
       aes(x = BMI, y = Cholesterol)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.6) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    axis.line = element_line(
      color = "black", 
      linewidth = 1),
    panel.grid.major = element_line(
      color = "gray70", 
      linewidth = 0.5, 
      linetype = "dashed")
  )

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 3
text:
element_rect(): Background Customization




Code
ggplot(bp_data, 
       aes(x = Region, y = SysBP_0m)) +
  geom_boxplot(fill = "lightblue") +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.background = element_rect(
      fill = "lightyellow",
      color = "black",
      linewidth = 2),
    panel.background = element_rect(
      fill = "white"),
    panel.border = element_rect(
      color = "darkblue",
      fill = NA, linewidth = 1.5)
  )

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 3
text:
element_blank(): Removing Elements




Code
ggplot(bp_data, 
       aes(x = Age, y = SysBP_0m)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.5) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    panel.grid.major.x = element_blank(),
    axis.title.x = element_blank(),
    legend.background = element_blank(),
    legend.key = element_blank()
  )



Use: Clean up unnecessary elements for minimal designs

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 3
text:
Creating an Organizational Theme


Code
# Hospital/Clinical Report Theme
theme_clinical_report <- function(base_size = 12, base_family = "serif") {
  theme_bw(base_size = base_size, base_family = base_family) +
  theme(
    # Professional serif fonts
    text = element_text(family = base_family),
    
    # Plot titles - centered and bold
    plot.title = element_text(size = base_size * 1.3, face = "bold", 
                              hjust = 0.5, margin = margin(b = 10)),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = base_size * 1.1, hjust = 0.5,
                                 color = "gray30", margin = margin(b = 15)),
    plot.caption = element_text(size = base_size * 0.9, hjust = 1,
                                face = "italic", color = "gray50"),
    
    # Axis elements - clear and readable
    axis.title = element_text(size = base_size * 1.1, face = "bold"),
    axis.text = element_text(size = base_size * 0.9, color = "gray20"),
    axis.line = element_line(color = "black", linewidth = 0.5),
    
    # Panel - clean with subtle grid
    panel.grid.major = element_line(color = "gray90", linewidth = 0.5),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    panel.border = element_rect(color = "gray40", fill = NA, linewidth = 1),
    panel.background = element_rect(fill = "white"),
    
    # Legend - bottom position, horizontal
    legend.position = "bottom",
    legend.title = element_text(size = base_size, face = "bold"),
    legend.text = element_text(size = base_size * 0.9),
    legend.background = element_rect(fill = "white", color = NA),
    legend.key = element_rect(fill = "white", color = NA),
    
    # Plot background
    plot.background = element_rect(fill = "white", color = NA)
  )
}

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 3
text: Clinical Theme in Action

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 3
text:
Multiple Legends Scenario




Code
ggplot(bp_data, 
       aes(x = Age, y = SysBP_0m,
           color = TreatmentGroup,
           size = BMI,
           shape = Gender)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.7)



Three aesthetics = three legends!
Can be overwhelming…

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 3
text:
Removing Specific Legends




Code
ggplot(bp_data, 
       aes(x = Age, y = SysBP_0m,
           color = TreatmentGroup,
           size = BMI,
           shape = Gender)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.7) +
  guides(
    size = "none",    # Remove BMI legend
    shape = "none")   # Remove Gender legend



Keep only the most important legend(s)

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 3
text:
Legend Position




Code
ggplot(bp_data, 
       aes(x = Age, y = SysBP_0m,
           color = TreatmentGroup)) +
  geom_point(size = 2, alpha = 0.6) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    legend.position = "bottom")



Options: “right” (default), “left”, “top”, “bottom”, “none”
Or coordinates: c(x, y) where 0 ≤ x, y ≤ 1

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 3
text:
Global Theme Settings


Code
# Set global theme for all subsequent plots
theme_set(theme_clinical_report(base_size = 14))

# Update specific elements globally
theme_update(
  plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, face = "bold"),
  axis.text = element_text(size = 12),
  legend.position = "bottom"
)

# Now all plots use this theme!



Benefit: Ensures consistency across all plots in a document/report

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 3
text:
Module 3 Summary
What we covered:


Color theory and accessibility
ColorBrewer, viridis, and paletteer packages
Scale functions: manual, gradient, gradient2, continuous, discrete
Custom theme creation with theme()
Element functions: element_text(), element_line(), element_rect(), element_blank()
Serif fonts and professional styling
Organizational theme creation
Legend management and removal
Global theme settings



Next in Module 4: - Complex visualizations - Advanced composition - Exporting and reproducibility - Limitations of ggplot2

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 1
text:
What is Grammar of Graphics?


A systematic framework for creating visualizations
Developed by Leland Wilkinson, implemented in ggplot2 by Hadley Wickham
Treats plots as layered compositions of graphical elements
Separates data from aesthetics from geometry
Enables infinite combinations from finite components
More flexible than traditional plotting systems



Core Philosophy: Build complex visualizations by combining simple, well-defined layers

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 1
text:
Why ggplot2?


Consistent syntax across all plot types
Flexible and extensible - easy to customize
Professional quality output
Reproducible - code-based approach
Large ecosystem of extensions
Industry standard in R community



vs Base R: More intuitive, consistent, and powerful for complex visualizations

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 1
text:
The Seven Layers of Grammar


Data - The dataset being visualized
Aesthetics - Mapping data to visual properties
Geometries - Visual marks (points, lines, bars)
Statistics - Data transformations and summaries
Coordinates - The plotting space and axes
Facets - Subplots for data subsets
Scales - Mapping data values to aesthetics



Plus: Themes for overall visual styling

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 1
text:
1. Data Layer
The foundation of every ggplot2 visualization


Must be a data frame or tibble
Each row represents an observation
Each column represents a variable
Data should be in tidy format

Each variable in one column
Each observation in one row
Each value in one cell





Code
# Basic structure
ggplot(data = my_data)

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 1
text:
2. Aesthetics (aes)
Mapping data variables to visual properties


Position: x, y
Color: color (points/lines), fill (areas)
Size: size of points or line width
Shape: point shapes
Transparency: alpha (0 = transparent, 1 = opaque)
Line type: linetype (solid, dashed, dotted)
Group: group (for grouping data)




Code
ggplot(data, aes(x = var1, y = var2, color = var3))

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 1
text:
3. Geometries (geom)
Visual representations of data


geom_point() - Scatter plots
geom_line() - Line graphs
geom_bar() / geom_col() - Bar charts
geom_histogram() - Histograms
geom_boxplot() - Box plots
geom_violin() - Violin plots
geom_smooth() - Smoothed conditional means
And many more…



Key concept: Geoms are added as layers with +

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 1
text:
4. Statistics (stat)
Data transformations and summaries


Many geoms have default statistics
stat_identity - Use data as-is
stat_count - Count observations
stat_bin - Bin data into groups
stat_smooth - Add smoothed line
stat_summary - Compute summary statistics



Usually implicit: Most geoms automatically apply appropriate statistics

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 1
text:
5. Coordinates (coord)
Defining the plotting space


coord_cartesian() - Default Cartesian coordinates
coord_flip() - Flip x and y axes
coord_polar() - Polar coordinates
coord_fixed() - Fixed aspect ratio
coord_trans() - Transformed coordinates




Code
# Flip axes for horizontal bars
ggplot(data, aes(x = category, y = value)) +
  geom_col() +
  coord_flip()

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 1
text:
6. Facets
Creating subplots for data subsets


facet_wrap() - Wrap panels by one variable
facet_grid() - Grid of panels by two variables
Useful for comparing groups
Can have free or fixed scales




Code
# Facet by one variable
facet_wrap(~ treatment_group)

# Facet by two variables
facet_grid(gender ~ region)

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 1
text:
7. Scales
Mapping data values to aesthetic properties


Control how data maps to aesthetics
scale_x_continuous() - Continuous x-axis
scale_color_manual() - Manual color specification
scale_fill_brewer() - ColorBrewer palettes
scale_y_log10() - Logarithmic transformation
Control breaks, limits, labels, transformations




Code
scale_color_manual(values = c("red", "blue", "green"))

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 1
text:
8. Guides (Legends & Axes)
Helping readers interpret the plot


Axes: Show scale of position aesthetics
Legends: Show scale of other aesthetics (color, size, shape)
Controlled by guides() function
Can be positioned, styled, or removed
Automatically generated from aesthetics




Code
guides(color = guide_legend(title = "Treatment Group"))

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 1
text:
Building Plots Progressively
The power of layering

ggplot(data, aes(x = age, y = systolic_bp)) +        # 1. Data + aesthetics
  geom_point() +                                       # 2. Add points
  geom_smooth() +                                      # 3. Add trend line
  facet_wrap(~ treatment_group) +                      # 4. Add facets
  theme_minimal()                                      # 5. Apply theme


Each layer builds on the previous, creating complex visualizations from simple components

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 1
text:
Setup: Loading Packages


Code
# Load required packages
library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)
library(tidyr)
library(readxl)

# Load the blood pressure dataset
bp_data <- read_excel("../../data/PublicHealth_BP_Dataset.xlsx")

# Preview the data
glimpse(bp_data)

Columns: 22

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 1
text:
Data Preparation

# Create derived variables
bp_data <- bp_data %>%
  mutate(
    # BP change from baseline to 6 months
    SysBP_Change = SysBP_6m - SysBP_0m,
    DiaBP_Change = DiaBP_6m - DiaBP_0m,
    
    # Age groups
    AgeGroup = cut(Age, 
                   breaks = c(0, 30, 50, 65, 100),
                   labels = c("18-30", "31-50", "51-65", "65+")),
    
    # Hypertension status (Systolic ≥140 or Diastolic ≥90)
    Hypertension_Baseline = ifelse(SysBP_0m >= 140 | DiaBP_0m >= 90, 
                                   "Hypertensive", "Normal"),
    
    # BMI categories
    BMI_Category = cut(BMI,
                       breaks = c(0, 18.5, 25, 30, 100),
                       labels = c("Underweight", "Normal", "Overweight", "Obese"))
  )

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 1
text:
Handling Missing Data

# Check missing data
missing_summary <- bp_data %>%
  summarise(across(everything(), ~sum(is.na(.))))

# Display columns with missing data
missing_summary %>%
  select(where(~. > 0))

# A tibble: 1 × 2
  ExerciseFreq ChronicDisease
         <int>          <int>
1            2              2



Key variables with missing data: ExerciseFreq (44), ChronicDisease (75)

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 1
text:
Handling Missing Data: Strategies

# Strategy 1: Filter complete cases for specific analysis
bp_complete <- bp_data %>%
  filter(!is.na(ExerciseFreq), !is.na(ChronicDisease))

# Strategy 2: Use na.rm in calculations
bp_data %>%
  group_by(TreatmentGroup) %>%
  summarise(Mean_SysBP = mean(SysBP_0m, na.rm = TRUE))

# Strategy 3: Explicitly show missing as category
bp_data %>%
  mutate(ExerciseFreq = replace_na(ExerciseFreq, "Unknown"))

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 1
text:
geom_point(): Scatter Plots
Minimum Arguments: aes(x, y)

# Basic scatter plot
ggplot(bp_data, aes(x = Age, y = SysBP_0m)) +
  geom_point()


Use for: Showing relationships between two continuous variables

text: geom_point() Output

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 1
text:
geom_point(): Enhanced Version

ggplot(bp_data, aes(x = Age, y = SysBP_0m, 
                    color = TreatmentGroup)) +
  geom_point(size = 3, alpha = 0.6)


Adding aesthetics: Color by treatment group for comparison

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 1
text: geom_point() Enhanced Output

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 1
text:
geom_line(): Line Graphs
Minimum Arguments: aes(x, y)

# Reshape data for time series
bp_time <- bp_data %>%
  select(PatientID, TreatmentGroup, SysBP_0m, SysBP_3m, SysBP_6m) %>%
  pivot_longer(cols = starts_with("SysBP"),
               names_to = "Time", values_to = "SysBP") %>%
  mutate(Months = as.numeric(gsub("SysBP_|m", "", Time)))

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 1
text:
geom_line(): Time Series Code


Code
# Average BP over time by treatment
bp_summary <- bp_time %>%
  group_by(TreatmentGroup, Months) %>%
  summarise(Mean_SysBP = mean(SysBP, na.rm = TRUE))

ggplot(bp_summary, aes(x = Months, y = Mean_SysBP, 
                       color = TreatmentGroup)) +
  geom_line(linewidth = 1.5)



Use for: Showing trends over time or ordered categories

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 1
text: geom_line() Output

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 1
text:
geom_col(): Column/Bar Charts
Minimum Arguments: aes(x, y)


Code
# Average BP change by treatment group
bp_change_summary <- bp_data %>%
  group_by(TreatmentGroup) %>%
  summarise(Mean_Change = mean(SysBP_Change, na.rm = TRUE))

ggplot(bp_change_summary, aes(x = TreatmentGroup, y = Mean_Change,
                               fill = TreatmentGroup)) +
  geom_col()



Use for: Comparing values across categories (uses actual values)

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 1
text: geom_col() Output

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 1
text:
geom_bar(): Count Bar Charts
Minimum Arguments: aes(x)


Code
# Count of patients by smoking status
ggplot(bp_data, aes(x = SmokingStatus, fill = SmokingStatus)) +
  geom_bar()



Use for: Showing frequency counts of categorical variables


Note: geom_bar() counts observations, geom_col() uses y values directly

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 1
text: geom_bar() Output

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 1
text:
geom_histogram(): Distributions
Minimum Arguments: aes(x)


Code
ggplot(bp_data, aes(x = BMI)) +
  geom_histogram(bins = 30, fill = "steelblue", 
                 color = "white")



Use for: Visualizing the distribution of a continuous variable


Key parameter: bins controls number of bars (default = 30) k = 1+_2(n) - k = number of bins - n = number of observations in your dataset - log _2 = logarithm base 2

geom_boxplot(): Box-and-Whisker Plots
Minimum Arguments: aes(x, y) or aes(y)

                    fill = SmokingStatus)) +

Shows: Median, quartiles (IQR), and outliers

text:

                    fill = Region)) +

Advantage: Shows distribution shape better than boxplots

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 1
text: Practice Solution

title: Best Practices
text:
Introduction to Data Visualization

“The simple graph has brought more information to the data analyst’s mind than any other device.” - John Tukey



Data visualization transforms complex data into visual insights
Good visualizations tell a story
Poor visualizations mislead or confuse
Every choice matters - especially in healthcare

title: Best Practices
text:
The Big Idea
Can you summarize your message in one sentence?


Your “Big Idea” should be:

Articulate your point of view: What do you want your audience to know?
Convey what’s at stake: Why does this matter?
Be a complete sentence: Not just a topic, but a statement

Example: “We should implement early discharge planning because it reduces readmissions by 35%”

title: Best Practices
section: Principle 1: Choose the Right Chart Type
text:
Principle 1: Choose the Right Chart Type
Match your visualization to your data and message
Different types of data require different visualizations:


Simple text: 1-2 key numbers
Tables: Multiple precise values
Categorical: Bar charts (horizontal preferred)
Continuous over time: Line charts, area charts
Distributions: Histograms, boxplots, violin plots, density plots
Relationships: Scatter plots, correlations
Comparisons: Slopegraphs, small multiples
Part-to-whole: Stacked bars (avoid pie charts)

title: Best Practices
text:
Chart Type: Simple Text


Effective: When you have just 1-2 key numbers, text is more impactful than a chart. Makes the metric impossible to miss and allows for immediate comprehension.

title: Best Practices
text:
Chart Type: Table


Effective: Tables excel when precise values matter and units differ. Better than charts when readers need exact numbers for comparison or reference.

title: Best Practices
text:
Chart Type: Heatmap


Effective: Heatmaps encode values with color, making patterns instantly visible in large tables. Ideal for spotting trends across two categorical dimensions.

title: Best Practices
text:
Chart Type: Horizontal Bar Chart


Effective: Horizontal bars are preferred for categorical comparisons. Long labels read naturally, and length comparisons are easier than height comparisons.

title: Best Practices
text:
Chart Type: Grouped Bar Chart


Effective: Grouped bars allow direct comparison across two categorical variables. The gap between groups creates visual separation that aids comprehension.

title: Best Practices
section: Avoid: Vertical Bars with Long Labels
text:
Avoid: Vertical Bars with Long Labels


Ineffective: Vertical bars with long labels force text rotation, making reading difficult. Horizontal bars solve this problem naturally.

title: Best Practices
text:
Chart Type: Line Chart


Effective: Line charts emphasize continuity and trend direction over time. The connecting line helps viewers see patterns and predict future values.

title: Best Practices
text:
Chart Type: Area Chart


Effective: Stacked area charts show both individual trends and cumulative total. The filled areas emphasize volume and make the overall trend prominent.

title: Best Practices
text:
Chart Type: Multiple Line Series


Effective: Multiple series work when normalized to comparable scales. Different colors distinguish series while the shared timeline enables pattern comparison across variables.

title: Best Practices
text:
Chart Type: Scatter Plot


Effective: Scatter plots reveal relationships between continuous variables. The trend line and confidence interval quantify the strength and uncertainty of the relationship.

title: Best Practices
text:
Chart Type: Scatter with Categories


Effective: Adding categories to scatter plots reveals whether relationships hold across subgroups. Parallel slopes suggest consistent effects; diverging slopes indicate interactions.

title: Best Practices
text:
Chart Type: Boxplot


Effective: Boxplots show distribution shape through quartiles. The box contains 50% of data, whiskers show range, and outliers appear as points - all in one compact visual.

title: Best Practices
text:
Chart Type: Violin Plot


Effective: Violin plots reveal distribution details that boxplots hide. The width at each point shows density, making bimodal distributions and skewness immediately apparent.

title: Best Practices
text:
Chart Type: Density Plot


Effective: Density plots show smooth distribution curves, ideal for comparing shapes between groups. Overlapping areas make differences in location, spread, and skewness clear.

title: Best Practices
text:
Chart Type: Ridgeline Plot


Effective: Ridgeline plots stack density curves for easy comparison across many categories. The slight overlap creates visual flow while maintaining distinct distributions.

title: Best Practices
text:
Chart Type: Slopegraph


Effective: Slopegraphs excel at showing change between two time points. The slope angle immediately conveys magnitude and direction of change for each entity.

title: Best Practices
text:
Chart Type: Stacked Bar Chart


Effective: Stacked bars show part-to-whole relationships over time. Total height shows cumulative volume while segment heights reveal individual contributions.

title: Best Practices
section: Avoid: Y-Axis Not Starting at Zero
text:
Avoid: Y-Axis Not Starting at Zero


Ineffective: Truncating the Y-axis on bar charts distorts proportional relationships. What is actually a 3% difference appears as a 3-fold difference due to the missing baseline.

title: Best Practices
text:
Better: Y-Axis Starting at Zero


Effective: Starting bar charts at zero shows true proportions. Now it’s clear that all hospitals perform similarly at high levels with minimal variation.

title: Best Practices
text:
Avoid: Pie Charts


Ineffective: Humans struggle with angle and area estimation. Quick: is Respiratory or Other larger? Pie charts make simple comparisons unnecessarily difficult.

title: Best Practices
text:
Better: Horizontal Bar Chart


Effective: Horizontal bars make comparisons effortless. Rankings are immediately clear, and length differences are precisely perceivable unlike angles in pie charts.

title: Best Practices
text:
Principle 2: Eliminate Clutter
Remove anything that doesn’t add value


Remove chart borders and backgrounds
Lighten or remove gridlines

Remove redundant data labels
Direct labeling > legends (Gestalt principle of connection)
Clean up axis labels
Maximize data-to-ink ratio (Tufte’s principle)

title: Best Practices
text:
Data-to-Ink Ratio: Maximizing Information
Every drop of ink should represent data


Data ink: Ink that represents actual data points
Non-data ink: Gridlines, borders, backgrounds, decorations
Goal: Maximize the ratio of data ink to total ink
Remove chart junk: 3D effects, unnecessary colors, decorative elements
Keep only what serves comprehension

title: Best Practices
text:
Example: Default Plot (Cluttered)


Ineffective: Gray background, heavy gridlines, legend requiring eye travel, and borders all compete for attention. The data-to-ink ratio is low - most ink conveys no data.

title: Best Practices
text:
Example: Decluttered with Direct Labels


Effective: High data-to-ink ratio achieved by removing backgrounds, excess gridlines, and legend. Direct labels connect to data via proximity (Gestalt principle).

title: Best Practices
text:
Principle 3: Use Preattentive Attributes
Attention with attributes processed in <250ms


Color: Most powerful
Size: Indicates importance
Position: Spatial relationships
Intensity: Bold vs light
Use strategically - don’t dilute attention

title: Best Practices
text:
Example: All Equal (No Focus)


Ineffective: All bars are equal - where should the viewer look? No visual hierarchy means no clear message.

title: Best Practices
text:
Example: Strategic Highlighting


Effective: Red instantly draws the eye to the problem. Gray provides context without competing for attention.

title: Best Practices
text:
Example: Using Size for Emphasis


Effective: Size combined with color creates a clear hierarchy. The large red point in August demands attention while smaller gray points provide context.

title: Best Practices
text:
Principle 4: Gray and Bold Technique
Use color to highlight, gray to push back


Bold color for what matters most
Gray for supporting context
Maximum one bold color per chart
Creates instant visual hierarchy
Reduces cognitive load

title: Best Practices
text:
Example: Too Many Colors


Ineffective: Multiple bold colors fragment attention. When everything demands attention, nothing gets it.

title: Best Practices
text:
Example: Gray and Bold Applied


Effective: One bold color directs attention immediately to the problem area. Gray bars provide necessary context without distraction.

title: Best Practices
text:
Principle 5: Think Like a Designer
Visual design principles enhance communication


Accessibility: Colorblind-safe palettes
Alignment: Create invisible structure
White space: Let your data breathe
Contrast: Guide the eye
Typography: Readable, professional fonts

title: Best Practices
text:
Accessibility: Colorblind-Safe Palettes


Always use colorblind-safe palettes. Approximately 8% of men and 0.5% of women have color vision deficiency. Blue-orange combinations work for nearly everyone.

title: Best Practices
text:
Design Principles: Alignment & Spacing


Effective design: Generous margins, aligned text, strategic white space, and clear visual hierarchy make the message instantly clear and professional.

title: Best Practices
text:
Using Annotations Strategically


Annotations tell the story. The chart clearly shows what happened, when it happened, and why it matters - the viewer doesn’t need to guess.

title: Best Practices
text:
Before/After: Design Transformation


Design transformation: horizontal orientation, strategic color, descriptive title, reference line, and clean styling create a professional, focused message.

title: Best Practices
section: Principle 6: Tell a Story with Data
text:
Principle 6: Tell a Story with Data
Transform insights into narrative


Beginning: Set context (current state)
Middle: Show the problem/opportunity
End: Recommend action
Use descriptive titles that state your point
Guide your audience through the data

title: Best Practices
text:
Narrative vs Descriptive Titles


Narrative titles tell the story. The right chart doesn’t just show data - it communicates the achievement and its magnitude immediately.

title: Best Practices
text:
Small Multiples: Powerful Comparisons


Small multiples enable comparison. Same scales across panels make differences immediately visible. Trend lines show improvement rates at a glance.

title: Best Practices
text:
Small Multiples: Distribution Comparisons


Distribution comparison made easy. Procedure C clearly clusters below the target with minimal variation, while Procedure D shows high variability and longer recovery.

title: Best Practices
text:
Complete Story Example


Complete narrative: Beginning (context with peers), middle (intervention and dramatic improvement), end (current state showing success). Every element supports the story.

title: Best Practices
text:
Advanced Topic: Handling Uncertainty


Show uncertainty honestly. Confidence intervals demonstrate that even accounting for variability, the new treatment shows meaningful improvement over the standard.

title: Best Practices
text:
Advanced Topic: Distribution of Uncertainty


Full distribution view. The minimal overlap between distributions shows that the new treatment improvement is robust, not just a result of a few outliers.

title: Best Practices
text:
Advanced Topic: Correlation Matrices


Multivariate relationships at a glance. Correlation matrices reveal complex patterns - here showing BMI and stress as strongest blood pressure predictors.

title: Best Practices
text:
Common Pitfall: Cherry-Picking Time Ranges


Always show full context. The “growth” story disappears when viewing the complete timeline. Cherry-picking ranges is a common way to mislead.

title: Best Practices
section: Edge Case: When Breaking Rules Makes Sense
text:
Edge Case: When Breaking Rules Makes Sense


Breaking the “zero baseline” rule is appropriate when zero is meaningless (temperature, stock prices, pH). The focus should be on clinically meaningful variation.

title: Best Practices
text:
Summary: Six Core Principles


Choose the Right Chart Type - Match visualization to data and message
Eliminate Clutter - Maximize data-to-ink ratio
Use Preattentive Attributes - Guide attention strategically
Apply Gray and Bold - Create visual hierarchy
Think Like a Designer - Professional, accessible presentation
Tell a Story - Transform insights into narrative

title: Best Practices
text:
Key Takeaways


Every choice matters - color, position, size, titles
Less is more - remove everything that doesn’t serve the message
Context is crucial - never cherry-pick data ranges
Accessibility counts - use colorblind-safe palettes
Focus attention - one bold color, clear hierarchy
Tell the story - guide your audience to action

title: Best Practices
text:
When to Break the Rules
Rules are guidelines, not laws


Zero baseline: not for temperature, stock prices, or indices
Pie charts: acceptable for simple two-part comparisons
Multiple colors: when showing categorical data without hierarchy
The test: Does breaking the rule serve your audience better?
Always ask: Am I making the data clearer or just different?

title: Best Practices
text:
Resources & Further Learning


Books


Storytelling with Data - Cole Nussbaumer Knaflic
The Visual Display of Quantitative Information - Edward Tufte
Good Charts - Scott Berinato



Online


ggplot2 documentation
R Graph Gallery
Data Visualization Society
Storytelling with Data blog

title: Best Practices
text:
Thank You!
Questions?

Remember: The goal of data visualization is not to make beautiful charts - it’s to communicate insights that drive better decisions.
“The greatest value of a picture is when it forces us to notice what we never expected to see.” - John Tukey

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 2
text:
Module 2 Overview
Previously (Module 1): - Grammar of Graphics foundations - Seven layers - Basic geoms
This Module: - Aesthetic mappings deep dive - Faceting strategies - Built-in themes - ggthemes package

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 2
text:
Setup: Load Data


Code
library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)
library(tidyr)
library(readxl)
library(ggthemes)  # For additional themes

# Load and prepare data
bp_data <- read_excel("../../data/PublicHealth_BP_Dataset.xlsx") %>%
  mutate(
    SysBP_Change = SysBP_6m - SysBP_0m,
    AgeGroup = cut(Age, breaks = c(0, 30, 50, 65, 100),
                   labels = c("18-30", "31-50", "51-65", "65+")),
    Hypertension_Baseline = ifelse(SysBP_0m >= 140 | DiaBP_0m >= 90, 
                                   "Hypertensive", "Normal"),
    BMI_Category = cut(BMI, breaks = c(0, 18.5, 25, 30, 100),
                       labels = c("Underweight", "Normal", "Overweight", "Obese"))
  )

# Time series data
bp_time <- bp_data %>%
  select(PatientID, TreatmentGroup, SysBP_0m, SysBP_3m, SysBP_6m) %>%
  pivot_longer(cols = starts_with("SysBP"),
               names_to = "Time", values_to = "SysBP") %>%
  mutate(Months = as.numeric(gsub("SysBP_|m", "", Time)))

bp_summary <- bp_time %>%
  group_by(TreatmentGroup, Months) %>%
  summarise(Mean_SysBP = mean(SysBP, na.rm = TRUE), .groups = "drop")

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 2
text:
Global vs Local Aesthetics


Global aesthetics: Defined in ggplot(), apply to all layers
Local aesthetics: Defined in geom_*(), apply to specific layer
Local aesthetics override global aesthetics
Use global for shared mappings, local for layer-specific mappings




Code
ggplot(data, aes(x = var1, y = var2)) +          # Global
  geom_point(aes(color = var3)) +                 # Local (adds color)
  geom_smooth()                                   # Uses global only

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 2
text:
Global Aesthetics Example




Code
# Global color applies to both layers
ggplot(bp_data, 
       aes(x = Age, y = SysBP_0m, 
           color = TreatmentGroup)) +
  geom_point(size = 3, alpha = 0.6) +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = FALSE)



Both geom_point() and geom_smooth() use the color mapping

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 2
text:
Local Aesthetics Override




Code
# Local aesthetic overrides global
ggplot(bp_data, 
       aes(x = Age, y = SysBP_0m)) +
  geom_point(aes(color = TreatmentGroup), 
             size = 3, alpha = 0.6) +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", 
              color = "black", linewidth = 1.5)



Points are colored by treatment, but smooth line is black

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 2
text:
Common Aesthetics: Color & Fill




Code
ggplot(bp_data, 
       aes(x = Region, y = SysBP_0m,
           fill = Region)) +
  geom_boxplot(alpha = 0.7)



color: Outlines of geoms (points, lines)
fill: Interior of geoms (bars, areas, polygons)

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 2
text:
Common Aesthetics: Size




Code
ggplot(bp_data, 
       aes(x = Age, y = SysBP_0m,
           size = BMI, color = TreatmentGroup)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.6)



size: Point size or line width, mapped to continuous variable

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 2
text:
Common Aesthetics: Shape




Code
ggplot(bp_data, 
       aes(x = Age, y = Cholesterol,
           shape = Gender, 
           color = Gender)) +
  geom_point(size = 3, alpha = 0.7)



shape: Point shape (circles, squares, triangles, etc.)
Best for categorical variables with few levels (≤6)

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 2
text:
Common Aesthetics: Alpha (Transparency)




Code
ggplot(bp_data, 
       aes(x = BMI, y = SysBP_0m,
           alpha = Cholesterol)) +
  geom_point(size = 3, color = "darkred")



alpha: Transparency (0 = transparent, 1 = opaque)
Useful for showing density in overplotted data

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 2
text:
Multiple Aesthetics Combined




Code
ggplot(bp_data, 
       aes(x = Age, y = SysBP_0m,
           color = TreatmentGroup,
           shape = Gender,
           size = BMI)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.6)



Can combine multiple aesthetics, but be careful not to overwhelm!

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 2
section: Aesthetic Mapping: Inside vs Outside aes()
text:
Aesthetic Mapping: Inside vs Outside aes()




Code
# MAPPED to data (inside aes)
ggplot(bp_data, 
       aes(x = Age, y = SysBP_0m,
           color = TreatmentGroup)) +
  geom_point(size = 3)

# FIXED value (outside aes)
ggplot(bp_data, 
       aes(x = Age, y = SysBP_0m)) +
  geom_point(color = "blue", size = 3)



Key rule: Inside aes() = mapped to data, Outside = fixed value

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 2
text:
Common Pitfall: Mapping Constants




Code
# WRONG - Don't map constants
ggplot(bp_data, 
       aes(x = Age, y = SysBP_0m,
           color = "blue")) +        # ❌
  geom_point()

# CORRECT - Set fixed values outside aes
ggplot(bp_data, 
       aes(x = Age, y = SysBP_0m)) +
  geom_point(color = "blue")         # ✓

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 2
text:
facet_wrap(): Single Variable Faceting




Code
ggplot(bp_data, 
       aes(x = Age, y = SysBP_0m)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.6, size = 2) +
  facet_wrap(~ TreatmentGroup) +
  theme_minimal()



Use for: Creating subplots for each level of one categorical variable

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 2
text:
facet_wrap(): Multiple Columns




Code
ggplot(bp_data, 
       aes(x = BMI, y = Cholesterol)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.6, color = "darkred") +
  facet_wrap(~ Region, ncol = 2) +
  theme_minimal()



ncol parameter controls layout columns

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 2
text:
facet_grid(): Two Variable Grid




Code
ggplot(bp_data, 
       aes(x = Age, y = SysBP_0m)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.5, size = 1.5) +
  facet_grid(Gender ~ TreatmentGroup) +
  theme_minimal()



Use for: Creating a grid with rows and columns from two variables
Formula: rows ~ columns

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 2
text:
Free Scales in Facets




Code
# Create data with different ranges
smoking_bp <- bp_data %>%
  filter(!is.na(SmokingStatus)) %>%
  pivot_longer(cols = c(SysBP_0m, DiaBP_0m),
               names_to = "BP_Type",
               values_to = "Value")

ggplot(smoking_bp, aes(x = SmokingStatus, y = Value)) +
  geom_boxplot(fill = "lightblue") +
  facet_wrap(~ BP_Type, scales = "free_y")



scales: “fixed” (default), “free”, “free_x”, “free_y”

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 2
text:
Facets with Multiple Geoms




Code
ggplot(bp_data, 
       aes(x = Age, y = SysBP_0m)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.4, size = 1.5) +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", 
              color = "darkred", se = TRUE) +
  facet_wrap(~ TreatmentGroup) +
  theme_minimal()



Each facet gets all layers - points and smooth line

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 2
text:
Complex Faceting Example




Code
# Handle missing data
bp_complete <- bp_data %>%
  filter(!is.na(ExerciseFreq))

ggplot(bp_complete, 
       aes(x = AgeGroup, y = SysBP_Change,
           fill = TreatmentGroup)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  facet_wrap(~ ExerciseFreq, ncol = 3) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(axis.text.x = 
          element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1))

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 2
text:
Theme System Overview


Themes control non-data elements of plots
Affect: fonts, colors, backgrounds, grid lines, axes
ggplot2 includes 8 built-in complete themes
Each theme suited for different contexts
Can be customized further with theme() function



Basic usage: + theme_minimal()

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 2
text:
theme_gray() - Default Theme




Code
ggplot(bp_data, 
       aes(x = Region, y = SysBP_0m, 
           fill = Region)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  theme_gray(base_size = 14)



Characteristics: Gray background, white grid lines
Best for: General exploratory analysis, default choice

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 2
text:
theme_bw() - Black and White




Code
ggplot(bp_data, 
       aes(x = Region, y = SysBP_0m, 
           fill = Region)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  theme_bw(base_size = 14)



Characteristics: White background, gray grid lines, black border
Best for: Professional reports, publications, clean appearance

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 2
text:
theme_minimal() - Minimalist




Code
ggplot(bp_data, 
       aes(x = Region, y = SysBP_0m, 
           fill = Region)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  theme_minimal(base_size = 14)



Characteristics: No background, minimal grid lines
Best for: Presentations, modern clean look, focus on data

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 2
text:
theme_classic() - Classic Look




Code
ggplot(bp_data, 
       aes(x = Region, y = SysBP_0m, 
           fill = Region)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  theme_classic(base_size = 14)



Characteristics: White background, no grid, axis lines only
Best for: Scientific publications, traditional journals, base R style

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 2
text:
theme_light() & theme_dark()




Code
# Light theme
ggplot(bp_data, 
       aes(x = Age, y = SysBP_0m)) +
  geom_point(color = "steelblue") +
  theme_light(base_size = 14)










Code
# Dark theme
ggplot(bp_data, 
       aes(x = Age, y = SysBP_0m)) +
  geom_point(color = "cyan") +
  theme_dark(base_size = 14)

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 2
text:
theme_void() - Completely Blank




Code
ggplot(bp_data, 
       aes(x = Longitude, y = Latitude,
           color = Region)) +
  geom_point(size = 3, alpha = 0.7) +
  theme_void()



Characteristics: No axes, no grid, no background
Best for: Maps, specialized graphics, pure data visualization

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 2
text: Theme Comparison

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 2
text:
ggthemes Package Overview


Additional themes inspired by famous publications and software
Professional, publication-ready aesthetics
Color palettes matching each theme
Includes themes from: Economist, FiveThirtyEight, Tufte, WSJ, Stata, Excel, and more




Code
library(ggthemes)

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 2
text:
theme_economist() - The Economist Style




Code
ggplot(bp_summary, 
       aes(x = Months, y = Mean_SysBP,
           color = TreatmentGroup)) +
  geom_line(linewidth = 1.5) +
  scale_color_economist() +
  theme_economist()



Style: Blue background, distinctive typography
Use for: Business reports, policy documents, professional presentations

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 2
text:
theme_fivethirtyeight()




Code
# Region summary
region_summary <- bp_data %>%
  group_by(Region) %>%
  summarise(Mean_SysBP = mean(SysBP_0m),
            N = n())

ggplot(region_summary, 
       aes(x = reorder(Region, -Mean_SysBP), 
           y = Mean_SysBP, fill = Region)) +
  geom_col() +
  theme_fivethirtyeight()



Style: Gray background, bold colors, large text
Use for: Data journalism, blog posts, engaging visualizations

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 2
text:
theme_tufte() - Minimalism




Code
ggplot(bp_data, 
       aes(x = Age, y = SysBP_0m)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.5) +
  theme_tufte(base_size = 14)



Style: Minimal ink, maximum data-ink ratio
Use for: Scientific papers, when “less is more”

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 2
text:
theme_few() - Stephen Few’s Style




Code
ggplot(bp_data %>% filter(!is.na(BMI_Category)), 
       aes(x = BMI_Category, y = Cholesterol,
           fill = BMI_Category)) +
  geom_boxplot() +
  scale_fill_few() +
  theme_few()



Style: Clean, professional, colorblind-friendly
Use for: Business intelligence, dashboards

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 2
text:
When to Use Which Theme?








Theme
Best For
Avoid When




theme_gray()
Exploratory analysis
Publications


theme_bw()
Reports, professional docs
Presentations


theme_minimal()
Presentations, modern look
Traditional journals


theme_classic()
Scientific publications
Web/digital


theme_economist()
Business reports
Academic papers


theme_fivethirtyeight()
Data journalism
Formal reports


theme_tufte()

Need context/grid


theme_few()
Dashboards, BI
Decorative needs

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 2
text:
Module 2 Summary
What we covered:


Global vs local aesthetics
Common aesthetic mappings (color, fill, size, shape, alpha)
Inside vs outside aes()
facet_wrap() and facet_grid()
Free scales in facets
Built-in themes (gray, bw, minimal, classic, light, dark, void)
ggthemes package (economist, fivethirtyeight, tufte, few)



Next in Module 3: - Color palettes and accessibility - Scale functions deep dive - Custom theme creation with theme()

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 4
text:
Module 4 Overview
Previously: - Module 1: Foundations & Geoms - Module 2: Aesthetics, Faceting & Themes - Module 3: Colors, Scales & Custom Themes
This Module (FINAL): - Complex visualizations with progressive builds - Advanced composition techniques - Exporting and reproducibility - Limitations of ggplot2 - Best practices and common pitfalls - Workshop summary

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 4
text:
Setup


Code
library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)
library(tidyr)
library(readxl)
library(ggthemes)
library(paletteer)
library(patchwork)
# remotes::install_github("haleyjeppson/ggmosaic")
library(ggmosaic)  # For mosaic plots

# Load data with all transformations
bp_data <- read_excel("../../data/PublicHealth_BP_Dataset.xlsx") %>%
  mutate(
    SysBP_Change = SysBP_6m - SysBP_0m,
    DiaBP_Change = DiaBP_6m - DiaBP_0m,
    AgeGroup = cut(Age, breaks = c(0, 30, 50, 65, 100),
                   labels = c("18-30", "31-50", "51-65", "65+")),
    Hypertension_Baseline = ifelse(SysBP_0m >= 140 | DiaBP_0m >= 90, 
                                   "Hypertensive", "Normal"),
    BMI_Category = cut(BMI, breaks = c(0, 18.5, 25, 30, 100),
                       labels = c("Underweight", "Normal", "Overweight", "Obese"))
  )

# Time series
bp_time <- bp_data %>%
  select(PatientID, TreatmentGroup, SysBP_0m, SysBP_3m, SysBP_6m) %>%
  pivot_longer(cols = starts_with("SysBP"),
               names_to = "Time", values_to = "SysBP") %>%
  mutate(Months = as.numeric(gsub("SysBP_|m", "", Time)))

# Summary data
bp_summary <- bp_time %>%
  group_by(TreatmentGroup, Months) %>%
  summarise(Mean_SysBP = mean(SysBP, na.rm = TRUE), .groups = "drop")

ci_data <- bp_time %>%
  group_by(TreatmentGroup, Months) %>%
  summarise(Mean = mean(SysBP), SE = sd(SysBP) / sqrt(n()), .groups = "drop")

# Custom theme from Module 3
theme_clinical_report <- function(base_size = 12, base_family = "serif") {
  theme_bw(base_size = base_size, base_family = base_family) +
  theme(
    text = element_text(family = base_family),
    plot.title = element_text(size = base_size * 1.3, face = "bold", 
                              hjust = 0.5, margin = margin(b = 10)),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = base_size * 1.1, hjust = 0.5,
                                 color = "gray30", margin = margin(b = 15)),
    plot.caption = element_text(size = base_size * 0.9, hjust = 1,
                                face = "italic", color = "gray50"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = base_size * 1.1, face = "bold"),
    axis.text = element_text(size = base_size * 0.9, color = "gray20"),
    axis.line = element_line(color = "black", linewidth = 0.5),
    panel.grid.major = element_line(color = "gray90", linewidth = 0.5),
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    panel.border = element_rect(color = "gray40", fill = NA, linewidth = 1),
    panel.background = element_rect(fill = "white"),
    legend.position = "bottom",
    legend.title = element_text(size = base_size, face = "bold"),
    legend.text = element_text(size = base_size * 0.9),
    legend.background = element_rect(fill = "white", color = NA),
    legend.key = element_rect(fill = "white", color = NA),
    plot.background = element_rect(fill = "white", color = NA)
  )
}

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 4
text:
Progressive Build: Starting Simple


Code
# Step 1: Basic plot
p_base <- ggplot(bp_data, 
                 aes(x = Age, y = SysBP_0m,
                     color = TreatmentGroup)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.6, size = 2)

p_base

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 4
text: Progressive Build: Step 1 Output

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 4
text:
Progressive Build: Add Trend Lines


Code
# Step 2: Add smooth trends
p_trend <- p_base +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = TRUE, 
              linewidth = 1.2)

p_trend

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 4
text: Progressive Build: Step 2 Output

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 4
text:
Progressive Build: Apply Theme


Code
# Step 3: Apply professional theme
p_themed <- p_trend +
  theme_clinical_report(base_size = 14)

p_themed

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 4
text: Progressive Build: Step 3 Output

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 4
text:
Progressive Build: Final Polish




Code
# Step 4: Final customization
p_final <- p_themed +
  scale_color_manual(
    values = c("Control" = "steelblue",
               "Intervention" = "darkred"),
    name = "Treatment Group") +
  labs(title = "Age vs Baseline Systolic BP",
       subtitle = "With linear trend lines",
       x = "Age (years)",
       y = "Systolic BP (mmHg)",
       caption = "n=200 patients")

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 4
text:
Multi-Geom Plot: Points + Line + Ribbon




Code
ggplot(ci_data, 
       aes(x = Months, y = Mean,
           color = TreatmentGroup,
           fill = TreatmentGroup)) +
  # Confidence band
  geom_ribbon(aes(ymin = Mean - 1.96*SE,
                  ymax = Mean + 1.96*SE),
              alpha = 0.2, color = NA) +
  # Trend line
  geom_line(linewidth = 1.5) +
  # Data points
  geom_point(size = 3) +
  scale_color_manual(
    values = c("steelblue", "darkred")) +
  scale_fill_manual(
    values = c("steelblue", "darkred"))

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 4
text:
Combining Geoms Strategically




Code
ggplot(bp_data, 
       aes(x = AgeGroup, y = SysBP_Change,
           fill = TreatmentGroup)) +
  # Individual points with jitter
  geom_jitter(aes(color = TreatmentGroup),
              alpha = 0.3, width = 0.2,
              size = 1.5, show.legend = FALSE) +
  # Box plot overlay
  geom_boxplot(alpha = 0.6, outlier.shape = NA) +
  # Add mean as point
  stat_summary(fun = mean, geom = "point",
               size = 3, color = "black", shape = 18)

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 4
text:
Publication-Ready Plot: All Elements


Code
publication_plot <- ggplot(bp_data, 
                           aes(x = BMI, y = Cholesterol,
                               color = Hypertension_Baseline)) +
  # Data layer
  geom_point(size = 2.5, alpha = 0.6) +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm", se = TRUE, linewidth = 1.2) +
  
  # Scales
  scale_color_manual(
    values = c("Normal" = "forestgreen", "Hypertensive" = "darkred"),
    name = "Baseline BP Status") +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(15, 40, 5)) +
  scale_y_continuous(breaks = seq(100, 300, 50)) +
  
  # Labels
  labs(
    title = "Relationship Between BMI and Cholesterol",
    subtitle = "Stratified by baseline hypertension status",
    x = "Body Mass Index (kg/m²)",
    y = "Total Cholesterol (mg/dL)",
    caption = "Data: Public Health BP Dataset | n=200 patients | Linear regression with 95% CI"
  ) +
  
  # Theme
  theme_clinical_report(base_size = 14) +
  theme(
    legend.position = c(0.85, 0.15),
    legend.background = element_rect(fill = "white", color = "black", linewidth = 0.5)
  )

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 4
text: Publication-Ready Output

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 4
text:
Layer Ordering Matters




Code
# Smooth UNDER points
ggplot(bp_data, 
       aes(x = Age, y = SysBP_0m)) +
  geom_smooth(method = "lm") +  # First
  geom_point(alpha = 0.5)        # Second










Code
# Smooth OVER points
ggplot(bp_data, 
       aes(x = Age, y = SysBP_0m)) +
  geom_point(alpha = 0.5) +      # First
  geom_smooth(method = "lm")     # Second

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 4
text:
Coordinate Systems: coord_flip()




Code
region_summary <- bp_data %>%
  group_by(Region) %>%
  summarise(Mean_SysBP = mean(SysBP_0m), .groups = "drop")

ggplot(region_summary, 
       aes(x = reorder(Region, Mean_SysBP),
           y = Mean_SysBP, fill = Region)) +
  geom_col() +
  coord_flip()



Useful for: Long category names, horizontal bar charts

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 4
text:
ggsave(): Saving Plots


Code
# Create a plot
my_plot <- ggplot(bp_data, aes(x = Age, y = SysBP_0m, color = TreatmentGroup)) +
  geom_point() + theme_minimal()

# Save the plot
ggsave(
  filename = "blood_pressure_analysis.png",
  plot = my_plot,
  width = 10, height = 6, units = "in",
  dpi = 300)




filename: File path and name with extension
plot: ggplot object (defaults to last plot displayed)
width, height: Dimensions
units: “in” (inches), “cm”, “mm”, “px”
dpi: Resolution (72 = screen, 300 = print quality, 600 = high-res print)

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 4
text:
Supported File Formats


Raster (Pixel-based):

PNG - Best for web, presentations
JPEG - Photos, small file size
TIFF - High-quality archival



Code
ggsave("plot.png", dpi = 300)
ggsave("plot.jpg", dpi = 150)
ggsave("plot.tiff", dpi = 600)



Vector (Scalable):

PDF - Publications, printing
SVG - Web, editing in Illustrator
EPS - Legacy publications



Code
ggsave("plot.pdf", width = 8, 
       height = 6)
ggsave("plot.svg")
ggsave("plot.eps")

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 4
text:
Choosing the Right Format









Format
Use Case
Pros
Cons




PNG
Web, presentations, reports
Lossless, transparent background
Large files


PDF
Publications, printing
Scalable, professional
Requires PDF reader


SVG
Web, further editing
Scalable, editable
Not all software supports


JPEG
Web (photos)
Small files
Lossy compression


TIFF
Archival, high-res
Lossless, high quality
Very large files




Recommendation: Use PDF for publications, PNG (300 dpi) for presentations/reports

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 4
text:
Reproducibility Best Practices


Set seed for random elements (jitter, sampling)



Code
set.seed(123)



Document R and package versions



Code
sessionInfo()



Use relative paths, not absolute



Code
# Good: read_excel("data/bp_data.xlsx")
# Bad:  read_excel("C:/Users/John/Documents/data/bp_data.xlsx")



Version control with Git/GitHub
Use R Projects for project organization

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 4
text:
What ggplot2 Cannot Do Well
While ggplot2 is powerful, it has limitations:


Mosaic plots / Marimekko charts - Better with ggmosaic or base R mosaicplot()
3D plots - Not natively supported, use plotly or rgl
Network graphs - Use ggraph or igraph
Interactive plots - Limited, need plotly::ggplotly() or ggiraph
Sankey diagrams - Use ggalluvial or networkD3
Circular plots (beyond polar) - Use circlize
Very complex statistical diagrams - May need specialized packages

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 4
text:
Mosaic Plots


ggplot2 cannot easily create mosaic plots


Code
# Use ggmosaic package instead
library(ggmosaic)

ggplot(bp_data) +
  geom_mosaic(
    aes(x = product(TreatmentGroup, 
                    SmokingStatus),
        fill = TreatmentGroup))



Or use base R mosaicplot() for traditional mosaic plots

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 4
text:
When to Use Alternatives



Need
ggplot2 Solution
Better Alternative




Mosaic plots
❌ Not supported
ggmosaic, base mosaicplot()


3D visualization
❌ Not supported
plotly, rgl, plot3D


Network graphs
❌ Not supported
ggraph, igraph, visNetwork


Interactive plots
Limited
plotly, ggiraph, highcharter


Animated plots
Via gganimate
gganimate, plotly


Sankey diagrams
❌ Not supported
ggalluvial, networkD3


Circular plots
Limited (coord_polar)
circlize


Geographic maps
Basic
leaflet, tmap, sf

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 4
text:
ggplot2 Extensions Ecosystem
The good news: The ggplot2 ecosystem is vast!


ggmosaic - Mosaic plots
gganimate - Animation
ggraph - Network/tree diagrams
ggalluvial - Sankey/alluvial diagrams
ggiraph - Interactive graphics
patchwork / cowplot - Combining plots
ggridges - Ridge line plots
ggrepel - Smart label placement
ggforce - Additional geoms and stats
ggsci - Scientific journal color palettes



See: https://exts.ggplot2.tidyverse.org/ for comprehensive list

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 4
text:
Common Pitfalls to Avoid


Mapping constants inside aes() - Use fixed values outside aes
Too many aesthetics - Limit to 3-4 visual encodings max
Poor color choices - Always test for colorblind accessibility
Overplotting - Use alpha, jitter, or facets
Misleading axes - Always start at zero for bar charts
Too much clutter - Remove unnecessary grid lines, legends, or decorations
Inconsistent themes - Use theme_set() for consistency
Ignoring aspect ratios - Consider final output dimensions
Not saving properly - Use appropriate format and resolution
Forgetting reproducibility - Set seed, document packages

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 4
text:
Best Practices Checklist
Before finalizing visualizations:


Color: Use colorblind-friendly palettes (viridis, ColorBrewer)
Contrast: Ensure sufficient contrast between elements
Text size: Minimum 10pt for body text, 12pt+ for titles
Redundancy: Don’t rely on color alone (use shape, pattern, labels)
Simplicity: Remove unnecessary elements
Labels: Clear, descriptive axis labels and titles
Alt text: Provide text description for screen readers
Print: Test in grayscale/black & white
Simulation: Test with colorblind simulator
Font: Use readable fonts (avoid decorative fonts)

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 4
text:
The ggplot2 Building Process


Code
ggplot(data, aes(x = var1, y = var2)) +           # 1. Data + Aesthetics
  geom_point(aes(color = var3, size = var4)) +     # 2. Geometry + Local aes
  scale_color_viridis_d() +                        # 3. Scales
  scale_size_continuous(range = c(2, 6)) +         # 4. More scales
  facet_wrap(~ var5) +                             # 5. Facets
  labs(title = "My Plot",                          # 6. Labels
       x = "X Label", y = "Y Label") +
  theme_minimal() +                                # 7. Theme
  theme(legend.position = "bottom",                # 8. Theme customization
        plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5))

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 4
text:
Key Takeaways


Grammar of Graphics provides a systematic framework for building visualizations
Layering is fundamental - data → aesthetics → geometries → scales → themes
Aesthetics map data to visual properties (inside aes())
Geoms are the building blocks - choose appropriately for your data type
Themes control appearance - use built-in or create custom ones
Colors matter - always consider colorblind accessibility
Scales control how data maps to aesthetics - customize breaks, limits, labels
Facets enable small multiples for comparing groups
Consistency is key - use global themes and organizational standards
Know ggplot2’s limitations and when to use alternatives

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 4
section: What We Covered Across All Modules
text:
What We Covered Across All Modules

Module 1: Foundations & Basic Geoms - Seven layers of Grammar of Graphics - Essential geoms: point, line, col, bar, histogram, boxplot, violin, smooth, density, jitter - Data preparation and handling missing data
Module 2: Aesthetics, Faceting & Themes - Global vs local aesthetics - facet_wrap() and facet_grid() - Built-in themes and ggthemes package
Module 3: Colors, Scales & Custom Themes - Color palettes and accessibility (viridis, ColorBrewer, paletteer) - Scale functions (manual, gradient, continuous, discrete) - Custom theme creation with element functions
Module 4: Advanced Topics & Best Practices - Complex visualizations and progressive builds - Exporting and reproducibility - Limitations and alternatives - Best practices and common pitfalls

Code
# Text elements

plot.caption, legend.title, legend.text

# Line elements
axis.line, panel.grid.major, panel.grid.minor

# Rectangle elements
plot.background, panel.background, panel.border,
legend.background, legend.key

# Position
legend.position = "top" | "bottom" | "left" | "right" | "none" | c(x,y)

title: Grammar of Graphics: Module 4
text:
Bonus: Combining Plots with patchwork


Code
library(patchwork)

# Create individual plots
p1 <- ggplot(bp_data, aes(x = Age, y = SysBP_0m)) + geom_point()
p2 <- ggplot(bp_data, aes(x = BMI, y = Cholesterol)) + geom_point()
p3 <- ggplot(bp_data, aes(x = Region, y = SysBP_0m)) + geom_boxplot()
p4 <- ggplot(bp_data, aes(x = SysBP_Change)) + geom_histogram()

# Combine in various layouts
p1 + p2 + p3 + p4                    # Side by side
(p1 | p2) / (p3 | p4)                # Grid
p1 / (p2 | p3)                       # Complex layout



patchwork makes combining plots intuitive with +, |, and / operators

title: Introduction
text:
Introduction
Why Visualize Data?
Grammer of Graphics: the ggplot2 Philosophy
Foundations of Visualization
These concepts form the backbone of any ggplot2 plot. - Data – The dataset being visualized - Aesthetics – Mapping data to visual properties (aes()) - Geometries – Visual marks like points, lines, bars (geom_) - Statistics – Summarizing or transforming data (stat_) - Coordinates – Defining the plotting space (coord_) - Facets – Creating subplots for subsets of data (facet_wrap, facet_grid) - Scales – Mapping data values to aesthetics (scale_) - Guides – Legends and axes to interpret scales
Styling and Layout These elements refine the appearance and readability of plots. - Themes – Overall visual style (theme_*, theme()) - Color – Using palettes and contrast effectively - Labels – Axis labels, data labels (labs(), geom_text) - Titles – Plot titles and subtitles - Captions – Additional context below the plot - Margins – Adjusting spacing around plot elements - Annotations – Highlighting specific data points (annotate(), geom_label)
Structural Composition These concepts help build complex and layered plots. - Layers – Combining multiple geoms and stats - Customization – Tailoring plots to specific needs - Exporting – Saving plots (ggsave(), formats) - Reproducibility – Ensuring consistent outputs across sessions
Interpretation and Communication These ideas focus on the purpose and impact of visualization. - Data Preparation – Cleaning and transforming data - Data Exploration – Using plots to uncover patterns - Communication – Conveying insights effectively - Storytelling – Building narrative through visuals - Accessibility – Designing for diverse audiences
Advanced Techniques and Tools These extend ggplot2’s capabilities and introduce interactivity. - Interactivity – Dynamic plots with plotly, ggiraph - Animation – Time-based visuals with gganimate - Tools and Libraries – Supporting packages (ggplot2, patchwork, cowplot) - ggplot2 – Core package for layered grammar of graphics - Other R Packages – lattice, plotly, shiny, etc.
Mapping aesthetics to data variables - Common aesthetics: x, y, color, fill, size, shape, alpha - Aesthetic mappings are defined inside aes() function - Example: aes(x = variable1, y = variable2, color = category) - Aesthetic mappings can be global (in ggplot()) or local (in geom_*) - Global mappings apply to all layers, local mappings override global ones for that layer

title: Debugging Plots
text: Debugging plots are essential tools for diagnosing issues in data visualization and analysis. They help identify problems such as incorrect data representation, scaling issues, or unexpected patterns in the data. In this guide, we will explore various techniques and tools for creating effective debugging plots.
